Pitched slate roofs (lean-to to side aisles and to flanking bays; gabled to porch) with clay ridge tiles, cut-limestone coping to gables having cut-limestone gabled bellcote to apex to south-west (with pointed-arch aperture on carved stringcourse having moulded reveals, cast-iron bell, and cut-limestone coping having cross finial to apex), cross finial to apex to north-east, rendered buttressed chimney stack to flanking bay, and cast-iron rainwater goods on timber eaves.  Unpainted rendered, ruled and lined walls with cut-limestone date stone/plaque to gable to porch.  Pointed-arch window openings (in tripartite arrangement to chancel) with oculus window openings to nave forming clere-storey (pointed oval window openings to chancel) having cut-limestone sills, and fixed-pane fittings having leaded stained glass panels.  Pointed-arch door openings with tongue-and-groove timber panelled doors.  Pointed-arch window openings to flanking bays with cut-limestone sills, and replacement uPVC casement windows.  Set back from road in own grounds with unpainted rendered, ruled and lined boundary wall having rendered coping supporting iron railings, unpainted rendered piers having cut-limestone capping, and iron double gates having Fleur-de-Lys finials.

(ii) Graveyard to site with various cut-stone markers, pre-1840-present.
APPRAISAL: Occupying the position of an earlier predecessor as indicated by archival editions of the Ordnance Survey, thereby continuing a long-standing ecclesiastical presence on site a well-composed middle-size parish church makes a prominent visual statement in a rural landscape.  Exuding a pared-down Gothic theme elegantly-proportioned profiled openings together with fine detailing in limestone displaying high quality stone masonry all combine to identify the architectural design value of the composition.  Having been carefully maintained the church presents an early aspect with substantial quantities of the historic fabric surviving in place including delicate stained glass panels exhibiting expert craftsmanship.  Enhancing the setting value of the church an attendant graveyard contains a large collection of markers of artistic design importance.

NAME: Clifden House
COMPOSITION: Detached three-bay two-storey over part-raised basement Classical-style country house, c.1750, on a H-shaped plan comprising single-bay two-storey recessed central entrance bay having (single-storey) prostyle tetrastyle pedimented portico to ground floor, and single-bay two-storey projecting flanking end bays having two-bay two-storey side elevations forming single-bay two-storey returns to west.  Refenestrated.  Undergoing extensive renovation, 2004-5.  Hipped roof on a H-shaped plan (lean-to to portico behind blocking course) with replacement Bangor slate, 2004-5, clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks, and rainwater goods undergoing replacement, 2004-5, on cut-limestone eaves having iron brackets.  Unpainted roughcast walls on unpainted rendered base with tooled cut-limestone quoins to corners, and carved cut-limestone course supporting cut-limestone band to eaves.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, and replacement six-over-six timber sash windows, 2004-5, superseding replacement uPVC casement windows having some one-over-one and two-over-two timber sash windows to side (south) elevation.  Square-headed door opening under prostyle tetrastyle Tuscan portico approached by flight of nine cut-limestone steps (with cut-limestone columns supporting carved entablature, frieze having central panel, and carved surround to pediment having blocking course to parapet) with cut-limestone block-and-start surround having entablature over, and timber panelled door.  Square-headed door opening to rear (east) elevation approached by flight of nine cut-limestone steps with replacement glazed uPVC panelled door.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds.
APPRAISAL: Built for Lord Hamilton (n. d.), according to local tradition thereby explaining the distinctive H-shaped plan form, an elegantly-composed house of the middle size represents an important element of the mid eighteenth-century architectural heritage of County Kilkenny.  Classically-detailed the architectural design value of the composition is identified by refined dressings displaying high quality stone masonry including an elegant portico.  Having undergone one period of extensive renovation whereby much of the original fabric was replaced with inappropriate modern articles a further restoration project presently (2004-5) underway seeks to reinstate fittings alluding to the historic models on site, thereby restoring the integrity of the composition.  Forming the centrepiece of a substantial landholding (including 12402015/KK-20-15) the resulting assemblage forms an appealing cluster making a positive impression in the rural landscape: the ruinous remains of the sixteenth-century Clifden Castle in the grounds survive as an important reminder of the long-standing legacy of the site.

NAME: Lyrath House (Leyrath House)
COMPOSITION: Detached five-bay two-storey Classical-style country house, built 1863, possibly over basement with three-bay two-storey pedimented breakfront, three-bay two-storey Garden (north-west) elevation (having pair of bowed bay windows to ground floor) extending into four-bay two-storey lower return to north-east incorporating fabric of earlier house, c.1725, on site, and single-bay two-storey side (south-east) elevation extending into four-bay two-storey lower return to north-east incorporating fabric of earlier military barracks, c.1775, on site.  Hipped slate roofs (gabled to breakfront) with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks having carved cut-stone coping on corbels, and cast-iron rainwater goods on cut-stone eaves having paired consoles (cast-iron rainwater goods on moulded rendered eaves to returns).  Part ivy-clad unpainted rendered, ruled and lined walls with rendered quoins to corners, moulded stringcourses to each floor, and moulded surround to pediment having consoles.  Round-headed window openings to ground floor (some paired in bipartite arrangement) having camber-headed window openings to first floor (in tripartite arrangement to first floor Garden (north-west) Front having square-headed flanking lights; paired in bipartite arrangement to central bay) with cut-stone sills (on corbels to first floor), moulded rendered archivolts forming continuous course having keystones, and one-over-one timber sash windows.  Venetian window opening to first floor breakfront in rendered frontispiece having balustraded apron supporting cut-stone sill, engaged colonettes supporting entablature, panelled frieze, keystone to centre supporting segmental pediment, and one-over-one timber sash windows.  Camber-headed openings to bowed bay windows on cut-limestone steps with engaged Corinthian mullions supporting archivolts having keystones, stringcourses over, moulded cornices supporting balustraded parapets, and glazed timber French doors having overlights.  Round-headed door opening in rendered frontispiece on two cut-stone steps with engaged Ionic columns supporting dentilated dosserets, rendered surround to door opening having moulded archivolt incorporating keystone, and timber panelled double doors having overlight.  Camber-headed openings to (north) return with moulded rendered sill course, moulded stringcourse to first floor, keystones, one-over-one timber sash windows, and glazed timber panelled door having overlight.  Square-headed openings to (south) return with cut-limestone sills, six-over-six timber sash windows, and glazed timber panelled double doors to ground floor with one having fixed-pane sidelights.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds with gravel forecourt, and remains of landscaped grounds, 1863, to site.
APPRAISAL: An elegantly-appointed large-scale country house rebuilt for Sir Charles Wheeler-Cuffe (1832-1915) to designs prepared by John McCurdy (c.1824-85) after Dromana House (redeveloped c.1825), in neighbouring County Waterford (see NIAH Waterford County Survey 2003 (22902918/WD-29-18)), incorporating a number of pre-existing ranges on site including a mid to late eighteenth-century military barracks.  Robustly detailed in the Classical manner a range of distinctive attributes enhance the architectural design value of the composition while refined embellishments in a combination of render and stone displaying high quality craftsmanship further enrich the external expression of the composition.  Having historically been well maintained the house presents an early aspect with the original form and massing surviving in place together with most of the early fabric both to the exterior and to the interior.  Despite preliminary works having been undertaken to redevelop the estate most of the attributes of the grounds landscaped to designs alternatively attributed to James Howe (fl. c.1860), Ninian Niven (c.1799-1879) or William Eden Nesfield (1835-88) survive intact for the time being, thereby contributing significantly to the setting values of the site in the local landscape.  The house remains of additional importance for the connections with the Wheeler, the Wheeler Cuffe, the Cuffe, the Stanton, and the Tupper families.

NAME: Lavistown House (Riverview House)
COMPOSITION: Detached three-bay two-storey house, built 1810, on a symmetrical plan with single-bay single-storey gabled projecting glazed porch to centre ground floor, single-bay two-storey lower recessed flanking bays terminating in single-bay two-storey gabled advanced end bays, and single-bay single-storey return to east.  Hipped slate roof (pitched to flanking bays; gabled to end bays; pitched to return) with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks having stringcourses, rooflights, and cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Pitched (gabled) glazed roof to porch in timber frame with finial to apex, and cast-iron rainwater goods on timber eaves.  Unpainted roughcast walls over random rubble limestone construction (exposed random rubble limestone construction to return).  Square-headed window openings (in tripartite arrangement to ground floor) with cut-limestone sills, six-over-six timber sash windows to ground floor (having two-over-two sidelights to tripartite openings), eight-over-eight timber sash windows to first floor (all having louvered timber panelled false external shutters), and two-over-two timber sash windows to first floor end bays.  Square-headed openings to porch with timber panelled pilaster mullions, glazed timber panelled door on cut-limestone threshold, fixed-pane timber windows on rendered sill, and fixed-pane overlight to gable.  Segmental-headed door opening to house with carved cut-limestone doorcase, timber panelled door having sidelights, and decorative fanlight.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds with landscaped grounds to site.
APPRAISAL: A well-appointed house of the middle-size displaying an elegant plan form alluding to an interpretation of the contemporary taste for the Palladian style whereby a central block extends through lateral ranges into end blocks.  Sparsely-detailed in the Classical manner the architectural design value of the composition is enhanced by attractive attributes including the detailing to the porch, the finely-crafted dressings to the door opening, the variety of glazing patterns to the openings, and so on.  Having been well maintained the house presents an early aspect with the original form and massing surviving largely intact together with most of the historic fabric both to the exterior and to the interior, thereby maintaining the character of the site in a rural setting.  The house remains of additional significance in the locality for the connections with the Warburton, the Colles (Collis), and the Nixon families.

NAME: Mill Mount (House)
COMPOSITION: Detached three-bay two-storey over basement Classical-style house with dormer attic, c.1775, on a cruciform plan with single-bay two-storey pedimented projecting entrance bay to centre, single-bay two-storey side elevations having single-bay full-height bows, and single-bay two-storey return to south.  Mostly refenestrated.  Hipped slate roof on a cruciform plan (gabled to entrance bay and to return; continuing into half-conical roofs to bows) with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks, slightly sproketed eaves, and cast-iron rainwater goods on moulded cut-limestone eaves having iron brackets.  Unpainted rendered walls with cut-limestone dressings including carved stringcourse to basement, quoins to corners, and moulded surround to pediment.  Square-headed window openings (lunette window opening to pediment) with cut-limestone sills, cut-limestone surrounds (no surrounds to basement), and replacement uPVC casement windows retaining eight-over-eight timber sash windows to basement having wrought iron bars.  Venetian door opening with cut-limestone surround including channelled piers supporting moulded cornice, moulded archivolt having keystone, timber panelled door having sidelights, and fanlight.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Road fronted.
APPRAISAL: A well-appointed Classical-style house built for William Colles (n. d.) with the scale and fine detailing suggesting a patron of substantial means having associations with the nearby Highrath Marble Sawing Mill complex (not included in survey).  Distinctive attributes enhancing the formal architectural design value of the composition include a Venetian door arrangement, elegant bows, and so on while limestone dressings displaying good quality craftsmanship further enliven the external expression of the house.  However, while most of the attributes survive in place including evidence of the original fabric to the interior the character of the house has not benefited from the insertion of inappropriate replacement fittings to most of the openings.

NAME: Highrath Flour Mill
COMPOSITION:
Remains of flour mill complex, c.1800, including:

(i) Detached three-bay single-storey mill manager's house with half-dormer attic.  In use, 1902.  Now in private residential use.  Hipped gabled slate roof (gabled to half-dormer attic windows) with clay ridge tiles, red brick Running bond chimney stack, timber bargeboards to gables, and cast-iron rainwater goods.  Random rubble limestone walls with remains of unpainted roughcast lime render over.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, red brick dressings (originally concealed), timber lintels to ground floor (one shared), and two-over-two timber sash windows.  Square-headed door opening with shared timber lintel, and timber panelled door.  Set in grounds originally shared with Highrath Flour Mill perpendicular to road with random rubble limestone boundary wall to perimeter of site.

(ii) Detached three-bay two-storey outbuilding.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, iron flue, rendered coping, and no rainwater goods on squared limestone eaves.  Random rubble limestone walls with traces of unpainted roughcast lime render over.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone shallow sills, concealed red brick dressings, timber lintels, and timber casement windows.  Square-headed door opening with timber lintel, and timber boarded door.
APPRAISAL: Representing an important element of the industrial heritage of Maddockstown the remains of a once-extensive flour mill complex survive as a pleasing, if subtle focal point in the local landscape: a collection of modest-scale ranges nearby provide an indication of the extent of the complex as originally established.  An adaptation to a private use has ensured that a modest-scale house retains most of the original architectural attributes together with substantial quantities of the historic fabric, thereby contributing significantly to the character of the site.

NAME: Maddockstown Saw Mill (Maddockstown Flour Mill)
COMPOSITION:
Flour mill complex, c.1775.  In use as saw mill complex, 1902, including:

(i) Detached five-bay four-storey building possibly originally with attic.  Now in ruins.  Pitched roof now gone with no rainwater goods surviving on ivy-clad squared rubble stone eaves.  Random rubble limestone walls partly collapsed with dressed limestone quoins to corners.  Camber-headed window openings with no sills, squared limestone voussoirs, and no fittings surviving.  Single segmental arch culvert with squared limestone voussoirs.  Set back from road in own grounds on bank of River Nore with overgrown grounds to site.

(ii) Detached five-bay five-storey double-pile building with attic with single-bay five-storey side elevations continuing through single-bay five-storey linking bay into five-bay five-storey parallel range.  Now in ruins.  Pitched double-pile (M-profile) roofs now gone with no rainwater goods surviving on ivy-clad squared rubble limestone eaves.  Random rubble limestone walls partly collapsed with dressed limestone quoins to corners, and sections of slate-hanging throughout.  Camber-headed window openings (some square-headed window openings throughout) with no sills, squared limestone voussoirs (lintels to square-headed openings), and remains of timber casement windows.
APPRAISAL: Having origins in the mid to late eighteenth century the remains of a once-extensive flour mill complex, later a saw mill complex represent an important element of the industrial legacy of Maddockstown.  Although now long disused many of the original composition attributes prevail including the regular distribution of small-scale openings producing a monolithic quality in the large-scale ranges.  Set in overgrown grounds the complex remains a picturesque, if subtle feature of considerable Romantic quality in the rural landscape.

NAME: Kilferagh House (Kilfera House)
APPRAISAL: Possibly having origins dating back to at least the mid to late seventeenth century as suggested by the position abutting a medieval tower house (pre-1647), thereby representing a site of considerable archaeological potential a middle-size house represents an important element of the early nineteenth-century domestic architectural heritage of County Kilkenny having historic associations with the Izod, the Ryan, the Davis, the Hunt, the Purcell, the Helsham, and the Stopford (Montagu-Stopford) families.  Alongside a small-scale contemporary (c.1800) counterpart at Kilfane House (see 12402845/KK-28-45) the house is distinguished by the attributes identifying a Regency-period cottage orn style.

NAME: Blanchville House
COMPOSITION: Detached three-bay two-storey over basement Classical-style country house, built 1800, with single-bay two-storey pedimented breakfront having (single-storey) prostyle tetrastyle Doric portico to ground floor, two-bay two-storey side elevations, and two-bay three-storey parallel range along rear (east) elevation extending into three-bay two-storey return to east.  Now in use as guesthouse.  Hipped slate roofs (part double-pile (M-profile); gabled to breakfront; pitched to return) with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks, and cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Painted rendered walls with cut-limestone chamfered stringcourse to basement, rendered quoins to corners, carved cut-limestone surround to pediment having modillions, and cut-limestone shield plaque to tympanum.  Square-headed window openings (in elliptical-headed recesses to ground floor) with cut-limestone sills, and six-over-six timber sash windows having three-over-three timber sash windows to basement with wrought iron bars (some three-over-six timber sash windows to parallel range to east).  Square-headed door opening under cut-limestone prostyle tetrastyle Doric portico (with half-fluted columns having responsive pilasters on three cut-limestone steps supporting frieze, moulded cornice, blocking course to parapet having raised central recessed panel, and decorative corner finials) with inscribed cut-limestone surround, and glazed timber panelled double doors.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds with tarmacadam forecourt, and landscaped grounds to site.
APPRAISAL: An elegantly-appointed substantial country house built in a style reminiscent of the output of Sir Richard Morrison (1767-1844) incorporating features redolent of the Regency period: although reputedly intended as the seat of Sir James Kearney (d.1846), Lieutenant General, it has been suggested that the house was originally occupied by Reverend Thobald Butler (fl. 1837) with the house reverting to occupation by James Charles Kearney in 1846.  Centred on a Classically-detailed breakfront the architectural design value of the composition is identified by characteristics including the balanced arrangement of pleasantly-proportioned openings, an enriched portico displaying expert stone masonry, and so on.  Having been very well maintained to present an early aspect the house retains substantial quantities of the original fabric both to the exterior and to the interior, thereby maintaining the character of the composition.  Representing the centrepiece of a large-scale estate (including 12402012, 18 - 9/KK-20-12, 18 - 9) the house makes a positive contribution to the scenic appeal of the local rural landscape.

NAME: Blanchville House
COMPOSITION: Freestanding single-bay four-stage Tudor Gothic-style bell and clock tower, built 1846-7, on a square plan.  Bells removed, 1930.  Undergoing restoration, 2004-5.  Irregular coursed tooled cut-limestone walls with cut-limestone dressings including stepped clasping corner buttresses rising through carved stringcourse to second stage as octagonal corner piers having carved stringcourses, cut-granite decorative panel to first stage having cut-limestone voussoirs over forming camber relieving arch, cut-granite shield plaque over, cut-limestone shield plaques to second stage, and carved cut-granite stringcourse to top stage supported on carved tapered corbels.  Pointed-arch window openings to first stage with cut-granite surround having chamfered reveals, hood moulding over supporting cut-limestone voussoirs, and carved granite decorative openwork panels.  Square-headed window openings to second stage (pointed-arch window opening over entrance) with cut-granite surrounds having chamfered reveals, hood mouldings over supporting cut-limestone voussoirs, mullions forming bipartite cinquefoil-headed arrangement now missing, and carved granite decorative openwork overpanels.  Oculus openings to third stage (originally accommodating cast-iron clock faces) with carved cut-granite surrounds having chamfered reveals, and continuous shared hood moulding over forming stringcourse supporting cut-limestone voussoirs.  Pointed-arch window openings to top stage with carved cut-granite sills on balustraded aprons, cut-granite surrounds having chamfered reveals, hood mouldings over supporting cut-limestone voussoirs, mullions forming bipartite cinquefoil-headed arrangement, and carved granite decorative openwork overpanels.  Pointed-arch door opening with cut-granite surround having chamfered reveals, hood moulding over supporting cut-limestone voussoirs, and replacement (temporary) timber boarded door, 2004.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Blanchville House.
APPRAISAL: Representing a dramatic landmark in the local landscape a picturesque bell and clock tower forms an element of national significance in the architectural heritage of County Kilkenny.  Built for James Charles Kearney (n. d.), son of Sir James Kearney (d. 1846), Lieutenant General, to designs prepared by Daniel Robertson (fl. 1812-49) reputedly citing Sir Christopher Wren's (1632-1723) Saint Mary's Church (1670), Aldermanbury, as a point of reference the tower exudes an ecclesiastical quality almost as if an accompanying nave of a church had since been cleared: deliberate discrepancies in the fabric suggesting the outline of a gable of an abutting range perpetuate this architectural chicanery.  Robustly detailed in a medieval-inspired manner the architectural design value of the tower is enlivened by refined dressings displaying particularly fine stone masonry.  Presently (2004-5) undergoing restoration following the provision of a grant by The Heritage Council the tower remains an important factor enhancing the aesthetic appeal of the Blanchville House estate.

NAME: Talbotshill Bridge
COMPOSITION: Two-arch rubble limestone road bridge over railway line and stream, rebuilt 1850, possibly incorporating fabric of earlier bridge, pre-1840, on site.  Random rubble limestone walls with rendered coping to parapets.  Pair of segmental arches with cut-limestone voussoirs, and squared rubble stone soffits having render over.  Sited spanning railway line and stream with overgrown grass banks to stream.
APPRAISAL: Representing an element of the civil engineering legacy of County Kilkenny an elegantly-composed modest-scale bridge exhibiting a traditional construction in unrefined locally-sourced stone makes a pleasing impression in the local landscape.

COMPOSITION: Section of formalised (canalised) river, established 1850, with random rubble limestone retaining walls having cut-limestone flagged decking.
APPRAISAL: Exhibiting good quality stone masonry with particular emphasis on the flagging to the river bed a section of formalised (canalised) river makes a pleasing, if subtle visual impression in a rural setting.

NAME: Clifden House
COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, c.1750, including:

(i) Detached four-bay two-storey outbuilding.  Reroofed, c.1975.  Pitched roof with replacement corrugated-iron, c.1975, iron ridge tiles, and replacement iron rainwater goods.  Random rubble limestone walls with iron S-profile tie bars.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, lintels, and timber fittings.  Square-headed door opening with lintel, and iron door.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Clifden House about a courtyard with random rubble limestone boundary wall to courtyard incorporating elliptical-headed carriageway having rubble stone voussoirs, and squared limestone coping supporting bellcote (with square-headed aperture having cast-iron bell, and squared limestone coping).

(ii) Detached two-bay single-storey outbuilding.  Extensively renovated.  Pitched roof with replacement slate, clay ridge tiles, rooflights, and replacement uPVC rainwater goods.  Random rubble limestone walls.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, red brick voussoirs, and replacement timber casement windows.

(iii) Detached two-bay single-storey outbuilding.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, rendered coping, and no rainwater goods on squared rubble limestone eaves.  Random rubble limestone walls with oculus apertures to gables having red brick voussoirs.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, dressed stone lintels, and timber fittings.  Square-headed door openings with dressed stone lintels, and remains of timber doors.

(iv) Detached two-bay two-storey outbuilding.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and cast-iron rainwater goods on squared rubble limestone eaves.  Coursed squared rubble limestone walls with oculus apertures to gables having squared rubble stone voussoirs.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, dressed stone lintels (shared to ground floor), and timber fittings.  Square-headed door openings (including one to first floor side elevation approached by flight of twelve stone steps) with dressed stone lintels (shared to ground floor), and timber fittings.
APPRAISAL: A collection of small- and modest-scale agricultural ranges informally arranged about a shared courtyard forming a middle-size farmyard complex contributing positively to the group and setting values of the Clifden House estate.

NAME: Lavistown House (Riverview House)
COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, established 1810, including:

(i) Attached three-bay two-storey outbuilding.  Hipped slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and cast-iron rainwater goods.  Ivy-clad random rubble limestone walls with dressed limestone quoins to corners.  Square-headed window openings with carved cut-limestone shallow sills forming sill course, lintels, and timber casement windows.  Square-headed door openings with lintels, and glazed tongue-and-groove timber panelled doors having overlights.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Lavistown House (Riverview House).

(ii) Attached five-bay single-storey outbuilding with attic with pair of square-headed carriageways to left.  Extensively renovated to accommodate use as offices.  Pitched slate roof with section of replacement artificial slate, clay ridge tiles, rooflights, and cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Random rubble limestone walls with section of ivy-clad unpainted render over.  Square-headed window openings with shallow sills, and replacement timber casement windows.  Pair of square-headed carriageways to left with replacement tongue-and-groove timber panelled double doors, and one with glazed tongue-and-groove timber panelled door having sidelight on tongue-and-groove timber panelled riser.

(iii) Detached three-bay double-height outbuilding.  Reroofed.  Pitched roof with replacement corrugated-iron over timber construction having iron ridges, and iron rainwater goods on timber eaves.  Random rubble limestone walls with dressed limestone quoins to corners, and painted corrugated-iron to gables.  Square-headed (full-height) openings forming open front with cast-iron banded pillars, and no fittings.
APPRAISAL: An appealing collection of modest-scale ranges forming a self-contained farmyard complex contributing positively to the group and setting values of the Lavistown House (Riverview House) estate.  Notwithstanding a number of modifications to accommodate an alternative use each range continues to present an early aspect, thereby having a positive bearing on the character of the site.

NAME: Lavistown House (Riverview House)
COMPOSITION: Gateway, built 1810, comprising pair of rusticated limestone ashlar piers with stringcourses, and carved cut-limestone cornice capping.  Road fronted at entrance to grounds of Lavistown House (Riverview House).
APPRAISAL: An attractive Classically-detailed gateway displaying high quality stone masonry making a pleasing, if subtle visual impression on the roadside at the entrance to the grounds of Lavistown House (Riverview House).

NAME: Blanchville House
COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, established 1800, including:

(i) Detached six-bay single-storey outbuilding.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Painted rendered walls.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, and timber casement windows.  Square-headed door openings with tongue-and-groove timber panelled doors.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Blanchville House.

(ii) Detached four-bay two-storey outbuilding with single-bay two-storey gabled advanced end bay having elliptical-headed carriageway to ground floor.  Extensively renovated.  Pitched roof on an L-shaped plan (gabled to end bay) with clay ridge tiles, and iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Ivy-clad unpainted replacement roughcast walls.  Square-headed window openings (in camber-headed recess to end bay) with cut-limestone sills, red brick voussoirs to end bay, and replacement timber casement windows.  Square-headed door opening in camber-headed recess with red brick voussoirs, and replacement glazed timber double doors.  Elliptical-headed carriageway to end bay with red brick voussoirs, and no fittings.

(iii) Remains of detached three-bay single-storey outbuilding originally with series of three camber-headed carriageways.  Renovated, c.1900, with openings remodelled possibly to accommodate residential use.  Now in ruins.  Pitched roof now gone with no rainwater goods surviving on cut-limestone eaves.  Irregular coursed dressed limestone walls.  Series of three camber-headed carriageways on dressed limestone piers remodelled, c.1900, to accommodate square-headed window openings in unpainted rendered surrounds over random rubble limestone construction with no sills, and remains of timber casement windows.

(iv) Freestanding cast-iron waterpump, c.1900, comprising fluted cylindrical shaft with stringcourse, moulded necking supporting cylindrical head having spout incorporating foliate motif, curvilinear 'cow tail' handle, and capping now missing.  Now disused.
APPRAISAL: A collection of small- and modest-scale agricultural ranges forming a self-contained farmyard complex alongside a further range (12402019/KK-20-19) in the grounds with the resulting ensemble enhancing the group and setting values of the Blanchville House estate.  Notwithstanding the loss of some of the original fabric as a consequence of an extensive renovation programme each range continues to make a positive contribution to the character of the site.

NAME: Blanchville House
COMPOSITION: Detached five-bay two-storey Tudor Revival stable building, built 1846-7, with single-bay two-storey gabled breakfront having box oriel window to first floor, and elliptical-headed carriageways to ground floor flanking bays.  Extensively renovated and extended comprising two-bay two-storey recessed lower end bay to left to accommodate use as apartments.  Pitched slate roofs (gabled to breakfront; gabled to window openings to first floor in form of half-dormer attic) with clay ridge tiles, cut-stone chimney stacks, cut-stone coping to gables, and cast-iron rainwater goods on cut-stone eaves.  Limestone ashlar walls to main block with cast-iron tie plates to first floor breakfront, cut-limestone shield plaques to gables, and ivy-clad unpainted roughcast walls to end block.  Paired elliptical-headed window openings to main block (including to box oriel window on corbelled jetty with hood moulding over, and battlemented parapet on stringcourse; some in single arrangement) in square-headed frames with cut-granite flush surrounds having chamfered reveals, mullions, and four-over-four timber sash windows having six-over-six timber sash windows to ground floor.  Tudor-headed door opening to breakfront with cut-granite surround having chamfered reveals, and glazed timber panelled double doors.  Elliptical-headed carriageways to flanking bays with cut-limestone voussoirs, and replacement glazed timber panelled double doors having fanlights.  Pseudo three-centred openings to end bays in elliptical-headed recesses having cut-limestone voussoirs with cut-granite surrounds having chamfered reveals, and glazed timber panelled doors.  Square-headed window openings to end block (in camber-headed recess to ground floor) with concrete sills, red brick voussoirs to ground floor, and timber casement windows.  Square-headed door opening in camber-headed recess with red brick voussoirs, and glazed timber double doors.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Blanchville House.
APPRAISAL: A well-composed middle-size outbuilding range reputedly built as a famine relief measure for James Charles Kearney (n. d.) in a style characteristic of the output of Daniel Robertson (fl. 1812-49) who was at the time preparing plans for the contemporary (1846-7) clock tower in the grounds (12402012/KK-20-12).  Exuding a Tudor Revival theme standing in contrast against the reserved Classicism of the main house (12402011/KK-20-11) the architectural design value of the composition is identified by distinctive characteristics including the glazing pattern to the openings, the many gables articulating the skyline, and so on.  Despite the purely functional purpose of the range the detailing throughout displays particularly fine stone masonry while the construction in a combination of limestone with granite produces a sombre palette.  Having been successfully adapted to an alternative use without adversely affecting the character of the composition the building remains an important element of a self-contained farmyard complex (with 12402018/KK-20-18) enhancing the group and setting values of the Blanchville House estate.

NAME: Blanchville House
COMPOSITION: Gateway, c.1850, comprising pair of limestone ashlar panelled piers with cut-limestone shallow pyramidal capping, iron double gates having spear-headed finials, sections of iron flanking railings on limestone ashlar plinth having spear-head finials, limestone ashlar panelled outer piers with cut-limestone shallow pyramidal capping, limestone ashlar curved flanking walls having cut-limestone coping, and limestone ashlar terminating piers with cut-limestone shallow pyramidal capping.  Road fronted at entrance to grounds of Blanchville House.
APPRAISAL: Forming an appealing feature at the entrance to the grounds of the Blanchville House estate an elegantly-appointed gateway exhibits very high quality in locally-sourced County Kilkenny limestone while early iron work further embellishes the design aesthetic of the composition.

COMPOSITION: Freestanding single-bay two-stage lime kiln, c.1825, on a square plan.  Now disused.  Random rubble limestone walls with base batter having dressed limestone tapered buttress piers, and dressed limestone quoins to corners to upper stage (coping now missing).  Pointed-segmental-headed oven aperture with tooled cut-limestone voussoirs, and lining not visible.  Set back from road in grounds of quarry with random rubble stone boundary wall to perimeter of site having cut-limestone rounded coping.
APPRAISAL: A kiln representing a modest-scale artefact of the industrial legacy of County Kilkenny having supported the operation of a limestone quarry on site since the earl nineteenth century.  Despite having fallen into the early stages of disrepair following a prolonged period of disuse the essential attributes survive in place including the profile of the oven exhibiting high quality stone masonry, thereby maintaining the position as a picturesque eye-catcher enhancing the aesthetic appeal of the local landscape.

NAME: Goat's Bridge
COMPOSITION: Three-arch rubble limestone road bridge over river, c.1825.  Widened, c.1975.  Random rubble limestone walls with rendered triangular cut-waters to piers, squared rubble limestone coping to parapet, and mass-concrete parapet, c.1975, to south on mass-concrete piers incorporating triangular cut-waters.  Three segmental arches with rubble limestone voussoirs, rubble limestone soffits, and reinforced concrete lintels to south forming three-span section.  Sited spanning tributary of River Barrow with grass banks to river.
APPRAISAL: Despite unsympathetic functional alteration works that have not had a positive bearing on the external expression of the composition the elementary attributes of a modest-scale bridge survive in place, thereby attesting to the position of the site as an important element of the early nineteenth-century civil engineering heritage of the locality.

NAME: Barraghcore Malthouse (Barraghcore Flour Mill)
COMPOSITION: Detached fourteen-bay six-storey Gothic-style flour mill, c.1800, possibly originally seven-bay six-storey with two-bay double-height projecting bay to left having single-bay four-stage engaged corner turret bartizan over on a circular plan, two-bay six-storey side elevations, and two-bay six-storey return to north.  In use as malthouse, 1902.  Disused, 1973.  Now in ruins.  Roofs behind parapets now gone retaining cast-iron rainwater goods.  Random rubble limestone walls with sections of unpainted render over, random rubble limestone parapet on cut-limestone stringcourse having cut-limestone chamfered coping, coursed dressed limestone walls to turret bartizan on cut-granite corbel table having slit-style blind apertures, cut-granite battlemented parapet on profiled corbels, and cut-granite dressings to projecting bay including quoins to corners having paired stringcourses over to parapet terminating in battlemented machicolations on profiled corbels.  Square-headed window openings in camber-headed recesses with cut-limestone sills, red brick block-and-start surrounds (most concealed), and remains of eight-over-eight timber sash windows having wrought iron bars (some red brick irregular bond infill panels).  Set in own grounds perpendicular to road with coursed dressed limestone boundary wall to perimeter of site having cut-limestone coping, unpainted roughcast piers having cut-limestone capping, and corrugated-iron double gates.
APPRAISAL: Picturesquely positioned overlooking the River Barrow an impressive large-scale range possibly completed over two periods of construction represents an important element of the industrial legacy of County Kilkenny having historically supported the local agricultural economy first as a flour mill and later as a malthouse.  Where mill buildings elsewhere in the county exhibit unassuming functional aesthetic aspirations the mill building at Duninga is identified by the robust dressings producing a Gothic theme enhancing the architectural design value of the composition: the treatment of the parapet having turret bartizans and machicolations in particular makes a prominent visual statement in the local landscape.  Although now long disused the original composition attributes survive largely intact including the pleasing pattern produced by the regular distribution of the openings across each elevation, thereby maintaining much of the integrity of the site.

NAME: Barraghcore House
COMPOSITION: Detached four-bay two-storey Classical-style country house with dormer attic, c.1850, possibly over basement incorporating fabric of earlier house, c.1725, on site with three-bay single-storey flat-roofed projecting porch to ground floor, single-bay two-storey advanced end bay to right, single-bay two-storey side elevation having canted bay window to ground floor, four-bay two-storey range along rear (west) elevation having single-bay full-height gabled advanced bay, and three-bay two-storey return to south-west.  Hipped slate roof on an L-shaped plan (pitched slate roof to parallel range continuing into return on an L-shaped plan; gabled to advance bay; gabled to dormer attic windows) with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks having moulded cornices, rooflights, and cast-iron rainwater goods on moulded rendered eaves.  Painted rendered, ruled and lined walls on tooled cut-granite plinth with rock-faced dressed limestone walls to porch having cut-granite dressings including block-and-start quoins to corners incorporating bull-nose detailing, frieze on stringcourse, carved cornice, blocking course to parapet, and painted roughcast walls to rear (west) elevation having rendered strips to corners.  Square-headed window openings (some in tripartite arrangement) with cut-granite sills (on cut-granite panelled risers to ground floor), moulded rendered surrounds (on consoles to canted bay window), and one-over-one timber sash windows having six-over-six timber sash windows to rear (west) elevation (some two-over-two timber sash windows throughout having eight-over-eight timber sash window to advanced bay).  Round-headed door opening to porch on two cut-granite steps with cut-granite panelled pilaster doorcase having moulded necking, paired consoles supporting open-bed pediment, bull-nose reveals to door opening, timber panelled double doors having overlight, square-headed flanking window openings on cut-granite panelled risers having block-and-start surrounds, chamfered reveals, and one-over-one timber sash windows.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds with tarmacadam forecourt, and landscaped grounds to site.
APPRAISAL: An elegantly-appointed substantial country house redeveloped for the Fleming family in the mid nineteenth century incorporating a substantial early eighteenth-century range in the grounds, thereby maintaining a long-standing presence on site.  Stylistically reminiscent of the contemporary (c.1850) View Mount (House) (12402107/KK-21-07) nearby suggesting the possibility of a shared architect or builder the architectural design value of the composition is identified by characteristics including the balanced arrangement of the pleasantly-proportioned openings, the arrangement of some openings in a Wyatt-inspired tripartite manner, and so on, all centred on an enriched porch displaying high quality stone masonry in the construction in a combination of granite and limestone.  Having been very well maintained the house presents an early aspect with the original fabric surviving substantially intact both to the exterior and to the interior, thereby maintaining the character of a composition forming the centrepiece of a large-scale rural landholding (with 12402112 - 4/KK-21-12 - 4).

NAME: Duninga Rectory (Grange Sylvae)
COMPOSITION: Detached five-bay two-storey over basement house, c.1800, on a symmetrical plan.  In use as rectory, pre-1837-post-1902.  Extensively renovated.  Now in private residential use.  Hipped slate roof with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stack on axis with ridge, and cast-iron rainwater goods on cut-granite stepped eaves.  Unpainted rendered walls with cut-granite stringcourse to basement, and replacement artificial slate-hanging to side (south) elevation.  Square-headed window openings with cut-granite sills, and replacement uPVC casement windows retaining three-over-three timber sash windows to basement having wrought iron bars.  Round-headed door opening on four cut-granite steps with cut-granite panelled doorcase having moulded necking supporting archivolt, and timber panelled door having fanlight.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds.
APPRAISAL: A middle-size house displaying a reserved treatment dependent on the balanced arrangement of Classically-proportioned openings centred on an enriched entrance bay for architectural effect.  However, although the retention of the original composition attributes maintains much of the integrity of the site the external expression of the house has not benefited form the replacement of substantial quantities of the original fabric: the survival of evidence of early timber joinery to the interior is therefore of particular importance.  Making a positive impression in a rural setting the house remains of particular significance for the historic role as a rectory throughout the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

NAME: Duninga House (Doninga House)
COMPOSITION: Detached five-bay three-storey country house, c.1775, possibly over basement with five-bay single-storey Doric colonnade to ground floor, two-bay two-storey projecting end bay to left (forming six-bay two-storey side (south) elevation), and two-bay three-storey projecting end bay to right (forming three-bay three-storey side (north) elevation).  Undergoing extensive renovation, 2004-5.  Hipped slate roofs on a H-shaped plan with clay ridge tiles, red brick Running bond chimney stacks, and cast-iron rainwater goods on cut-stone eaves having iron brackets.  Roof to colonnade not visible behind parapet.  Unpainted rendered walls to main block over random rubble limestone construction with unpainted roughcast walls to remainder (removed, 2004-5, from end bay to right exposing random squared limestone construction having dressed limestone quoins to corners).  Square-headed window openings (camber-headed to end bay to right; one in tripartite arrangement to side (north) elevation in segmental-headed recess having red brick dressings) with cut-limestone sills (yellow brick block-and-start surrounds to camber-headed openings), three-over-six, six-over-six, and six-over three timber sash windows (timber casement windows to camber-headed openings).  Round-headed door opening under Doric colonnade (with paired cut-granite columns supporting frieze, carved cornice, and blocking course to parapet) with carved cut-granite surround having keystone, and glazed timber panelled double doors having fanlight.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds.
APPRAISAL: Possibly evolving organically over a prolonged period of development as suggested by qualities including the complex form and massing combined with the lack of a distinct cohesive architectural or stylistic theme a large-scale country house forms an important element of the late eighteenth-century built heritage of County Kilkenny.  Various interventions over ensuing decades having left their mark on the fabric of the composition the house presents an untidy aspect: and yet the survival of that fabric contributes significantly to the historic character of the site.  Presently (2004-5) undergoing an extensive renovation project that includes the redevelopment of the surrounding grounds (including 12402115/KK-21-15) the house remains of particular importance in the locality for the long-standing historic associations with the Bookey, the Percy, and the de Montmorency families.

NAME: Barraghcore Bridge
COMPOSITION: Single-arch road bridge over river, c.1900, possibly incorporating fabric of earlier bridge, pre-1840, on site.  Unpainted rendered, ruled and lined walls with rendered triangular cut-waters, rendered stringcourse supporting parapet, and rendered coping.  Single arch (profile not visible).  Sited spanning Acore River with grass banks to river.
APPRAISAL: Possibly incorporating the fabric of an earlier crossing on site as indicated by archival editions of the Ordnance Survey a modest-scale bridge forming a pleasing feature spanning the Acore River represents an integral component of the late nineteenth- or early twentieth-century civil engineering legacy of County Kilkenny.

NAME: View Mount (House)
COMPOSITION:
Detached three-bay two-storey Classical-style country house, c.1850, possibly incorporating fabric of earlier house, c.1725, on site with three-bay single-storey flat-roofed projecting porch to centre ground floor, single-bay two-storey advanced end bay to right, three-bay two-storey side elevations, three-bay two-storey lower parallel range along rear (east) elevation terminating in single-bay two-storey higher end bay having two-storey canted bay window, and three-bay single-storey service range with half-dormer attic to south-east.  Now disused.  Hipped slate roofs (half-octagonal to canted bay window; gabled to half-dormer attic windows to service range) with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks having cut-limestone stringcourses, rooflights, and cast-iron rainwater goods on slightly overhanging cut-limestone eaves.  Roof to porch not visible behind parapet.  Unpainted rendered, ruled and lined walls with cut-limestone stringcourse to first floor, cut-limestone band to eaves, limestone ashlar walls to porch having chamfered pilasters with moulded necking, moulded cornice on stringcourse, panelled parapet rising into gable to centre, and cut-limestone coping.  Square-headed window openings (some paired; in camber-headed recesses to ground floor) with cut-limestone sills (forming sill course to first floor having panelled risers), chamfered reveals to ground floor, and one-over-one timber sash windows (square-headed window openings to service range with cut-limestone sills, and one-over-one timber sash windows).  Square-headed openings to porch with two cut-limestone steps, timber panelled double doors having overlight, and one-over-one timber sash sidelights.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds with tarmacadam forecourt, and landscaped grounds to site.

(ii) Attached six-bay two-storey outbuilding wing, c.1850, to south on an L-shaped plan possibly incorporating fabric of earlier house, c.1725, on site with elliptical-headed carriageway to ground floor, and four-bay single-storey projecting range to left.  Now disused.  Pitched slate roof (hipped gabled to projecting range) with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks having rendered stringcourses, and cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Unpainted roughcast walls over random rubble limestone construction.  Square-headed window openings (some in bipartite arrangement) with cut-limestone sills, concealed yellow brick surrounds, and remains of two-over-two timber sash windows.  Square-headed door opening with yellow brick block-and-start surround (originally concealed), and remains of timber door.  Elliptical-headed carriageway to ground floor with no fittings.
APPRAISAL: An elegantly-appointed substantial country house redeveloped for the Flood family in the mid nineteenth century possibly incorporating an early eighteenth-century range in the grounds, thereby maintaining a long-standing presence on site.  Stylistically reminiscent of the contemporary (c.1850) Barraghcore House (12402103/KK-21-03) nearby, thus suggesting the possibility of a shared architect or builder the architectural design value of the composition is identified by characteristics including the balanced arrangement of the pleasantly-proportioned openings, the paired arrangement of some openings, and so on, all centred on an enriched porch displaying high quality stone masonry.  Having historically been very well maintained the house presents an early aspect with the original fabric surviving substantially intact both to the exterior and to the interior, thereby maintaining the character of a composition forming the centrepiece of a large-scale rural landholding.  Despite having fallen into poor repair an attendant outbuilding range makes a positive contribution to the group and setting values of the house in the landscape.

NAME: Paulstown Castle
COMPOSITION:
Detached three-bay four-stage 'tower house' country house, rebuilt 1828, retaining fabric of earlier house, 1710, possibly incorporating fabric of medieval castle, c.1450, on site with single-bay two-storey projecting bay to right possibly originally single-bay single-storey.  In use, 1902.  Vacated, pre-1973.  Now in ruins.  Roof not visible behind parapet with limestone ashlar chimney stacks.  Pitched slate roof to projecting bay with clay ridge tiles, red brick irregular bond chimney stack, and no rainwater goods surviving on red brick eaves.  Part ivy-clad random rubble limestone walls to first and to second stages (red brick Flemish bond walls to projecting bay) having slight batter, traces of unpainted render over, cut-limestone stringcourses to each stage, tooled limestone ashlar walls to remainder (including to parapet having cross-style apertures), and cut-limestone coping.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, hood mouldings over to second stage, cut-limestone voussoirs over to remainder forming camber relieving arches, and remains of eight-over-eight timber sash windows having some random rubble limestone infill panels.  Square-headed door opening with no fittings surviving.  Camber-headed door opening to projecting bay (possibly originally camber-headed carriageway) with cut-limestone voussoirs, and no fittings.  Interior now derelict.  Set back from road in own grounds.

(ii) Attached three-bay single-storey outbuilding, pre-1840, to south-east.  Pitched roofs (stepping down with each bay) with clay ridge tiles, and remains of cast-iron rainwater goods.  Random rubble limestone walls.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, red brick dressings, timber lintel, and remains of timber fittings.  Square-headed door opening with timber lintel, and remains of timber fittings.

(iii) Detached three-bay single-storey gate lodge with dormer attic, post-1840, to north-east with single-bay single-storey gabled advanced porch to centre ground floor.  Refenestrated.  Now in private residential use.  Pitched slate roof (gabled to dormer attic windows and to porch) with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stack, timber bargeboards, and cast-iron rainwater goods on timber eaves.  Random rubble limestone walls with dressed limestone quoins to corners.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, lintels, and replacement uPVC casement windows.  Square-headed door opening with replacement glazed timber panelled door.

(iv) Gateway, pre-1840, to north-east comprising pair of unpainted rendered piers with cut-granite capping having ball finials on pyramidal bases, and random squared rubble limestone boundary wall to perimeter of site.
APPRAISAL: Representing one of the more intriguing elements of the architectural heritage of County Kilkenny a middle-size house of distinctive appearance takes the form of a gentrified or refined medieval tower house: positioned on the site, and possibly incorporating the fabric of a fifteenth-century castle the present house reputedly built to designs prepared by William Robertson (1770-1850) represents the continued long-standing presence in the grounds.  Although now apparently long disused many of the original attributes survive in place including the remains of the fittings to most of the openings.  A collection of attendant ranges including a pleasantly-composed small-scale gate lodge produces an appealing ensemble contributing to the scenic value of the local landscape.  The house remains of additional importance for the historic associations with the Flood family of nearby View Mount House (12402107/KK-21-07), the Healy family, and for the reputed connections with Sir Pearse Butler (n. d.).

NAME: Monefelim Bridge
COMPOSITION: Three-arch rubble limestone road bridge over river, c.1825.  Repaired, c.1975.  Random squared rubble limestone walls with tooled limestone ashlar triangular cut-waters to piers, ivy-clad parapet having cut-limestone coping, and replacement concrete block parapet, c.1975, to west.  Series of three segmental arches with dressed limestone voussoirs, and rubble stone soffits having traces of render over.  Sited spanning Monefelim River with grass banks to river.
APPRAISAL: Representing an element of the early nineteenth-century civil engineering of the locality a well-composed modest-scale bridge displaying a traditional construction in locally-sourced stone forms a pleasing focal point at a crossing over the Monefelim River.

NAME: Killure House (Garryduff Rectory)
COMPOSITION: Detached three-bay two-storey Board of First Fruits glebe house, c.1800, on an L-shaped plan with single-bay two-storey side elevations, and three-bay two-storey return to west.  In use, 1902.  Extensively renovated.  Now in private residential use.  Hipped slate roof on an L-shaped plan with clay ridge tiles, red brick Running bond chimney stacks having stringcourses, and cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Random rubble limestone walls originally rendered with render removed having dressed limestone quoins to corners.  Square-headed window openings (in camber-headed recesses to front (east) elevation) with cut-limestone sills, red brick dressings including voussoirs, and replacement uPVC casement windows.  Camber-headed door opening with carved cut-limestone doorcase (possibly replacement), and replacement timber panelled door having overlight.  Set back from road in own grounds.
APPRAISAL: A middle-size house retaining the original form and massing, thereby maintaining some of the character of the composition following the loss of substantial quantities of the historic fabric as a consequence of an extensive renovation programme.  The house remains of particular importance in the locality for the original intended use as a glebe house or rectory sponsored by the Board of First Fruits (fl. c.1711-1833).

NAME: Mountrothe House (Mountrath House)
COMPOSITION: Detached three-bay two-storey over basement house, c.1775.  Extensively renovated and extended, c.1900, comprising single-bay two-storey lean-to lower end bay to left with single-bay single-storey gabled projecting glazed porch added to centre ground floor.  Hipped roof on a U-shaped plan (lean-to to end bay) with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks, and cast-iron rainwater goods on cut-granite eaves.  Pitched (gabled) glazed roof to porch in timber frame with decorative timber bargeboards to gable having finial to apex, and cast-iron rainwater goods on timber eaves.  Ivy-clad unpainted roughcast walls with rendered strips to corners, and unpainted rendered wall to rear (south) elevation.  Square-headed window openings (Venetian window opening to centre first floor) with cut-limestone sills, moulded rendered surrounds to rear (south) elevation, replacement one-over-one timber sash windows, c.1900, retaining three-over-six timber sash windows to first floor (one six-over-six timber sash window to ground floor), and three-over-three timber sash window to Venetian opening having Gothic-style overlight.  Square-headed openings to porch with glazed diagonal tongue-and-groove timber panelled double doors having overlight, fixed-pane timber sidelights, and fixed-pane light to gable.  Venetian door opening to house with carved cut-granite surround having double keystone, timber panelled door having sidelights, and overlight.  Square-headed door openings to rear (south) elevation with moulded rendered surrounds, and glazed timber French doors having overlights.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds with tarmacadam forecourt, and landscaped grounds to site.
APPRAISAL: A well-composed middle-size house representing an important element of the late eighteenth-century domestic architectural heritage of County Kilkenny.  Sparsely-detailed the architectural design value of the composition is identified by the balanced arrangement of pleasantly-proportioned openings centred on an entrance bay incorporating Venetian-derived detailing: finely-crafted dressings including the fittings to the doorway further embellish the external expression of the house.  Having been carefully maintained the house presents an early aspect with the original composition attributes surviving substantially intact together with most of the historic fabric both to the exterior and to the interior.  Forming the centrepiece of a self-contained landholding (with 12402121/KK-21-21) the house remains of additional local significance for the historic associations with the Roth (Rothe), the Barton, the Brennan, the Walshe, and the McKenny families.

NAME: Barraghcore House
COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, c.1850, about a courtyard incorporating fabric of earlier complex, pre-1840, on site including:

(i) Detached three-bay two-storey outbuilding with camber-headed carriageway to right ground floor.  Hipped gabled slate roof with clay ridge tiles, rendered shallow gabled bellcote (with camber-headed aperture, and rendered stringcourse supporting gabled coping), and iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Painted rendered walls over random rubble limestone construction with cast-iron tie plates to first floor.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone shallow sills, and timber casement windows.  Square-headed door opening with timber panelled door.  Camber-headed carriageway to right ground floor with timber fitting having overlight.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Barraghcore House about a courtyard having random rubble limestone boundary wall incorporating elliptical-headed carriageway in dressed limestone screen with cut-limestone voussoirs, iron double gates, and cut-limestone coping to parapet.

(ii) Detached single-bay two-storey outbuilding.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods on dressed rubble limestone eaves.  Random squared rubble limestone walls with remains of unpainted roughcast over, and slit-style apertures to first floor.  Square-headed window opening with cut-stone shallow sill, and timber casement window.

(iii) Detached six-bay two-storey stable outbuilding with camber-headed carriageway to ground floor.  Hipped gabled slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods on dressed rubble limestone eaves.  Random squared rubble limestone walls.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills (no sills to ground floor), red brick voussoirs, and timber casement windows.  Square-headed door openings with cut-granite surrounds, red brick voussoirs forming camber relieving arches over, and timber panelled doors.  Camber-headed carriageway to ground floor with cut-granite surround rising into red brick voussoirs, and no fittings.

(iv) Detached five-bay two-storey coach house with series of three elliptical-headed carriageways to ground floor.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods on dressed limestone eaves. Random squared rubble limestone walls.  Square-headed window openings in camber-headed recesses with cut-limestone sills, red brick block-and-start surrounds, and timber casement windows.  Square-headed door openings with red brick voussoirs, and timber boarded doors.  Series of three elliptical-headed carriageways to ground floor with red brick voussoirs, and no fittings.

(v) Attached three-bay double-height outbuilding.  Hipped gabled slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods.  Random coursed rubble limestone walls with cast-iron tie plates.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone shallow sills, red brick dressings, and fittings not visible.

(vi) Attached four-bay double-height outbuilding with series of four elliptical-headed carriageways to ground floor.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods on squared rubble limestone eaves.  Random coursed squared limestone walls.  Series of four elliptical-headed carriageways to ground floor with red brick dressings, and fittings not visible.
APPRAISAL: An attractive collection of modest-scale and middle-size agricultural outbuildings arranged about a shared courtyard with the resulting cluster contributing significantly to the group and setting values of the Barraghcore House estate while indicating the various ancillary services historically necessary in the maintenance of a large-scale landholding.  Each range having been well maintained with most of the original attributes surviving intact the complex makes a positive impression on the character of the site.

NAME: Barraghcore House
COMPOSITION: Detached two-bay single-storey gate lodge, c.1825, on an T-shaped plan with single-bay single-storey projecting end bay to left, and single-bay single-storey return to east.  Now disused.  Hipped slate roof on a T-shaped plan with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stack on a profiled octagonal plan, and no rainwater goods surviving on cut-granite eaves having paired consoles.  Unpainted fine roughcast walls over irregular coursed dressed limestone construction.  Square-headed window openings (some in tripartite arrangement) with cut-granite sills, cut-granite surrounds having consoles supporting entablatures, and six-over-six timber sash windows.  Square-headed door opening with cut-granite surround having consoles supporting entablature, and tongue-and-groove timber panelled door.  Set back from line of road in grounds shared with Barraghcore House.
APPRAISAL: A picturesque small-scale gate lodge displaying robust detailing in the Classical manner with granite dressings exhibiting high quality craftsmanship enriching the architectural design value of the composition.  Although having fallen into disrepair as a consequence of a prolonged period of disuse the elementary attributes survive in place, thereby making a pleasing visual statement with the attendant gateway (12402114/KK-21-14) at the entrance to the grounds of Barraghcore House.

NAME: Barraghcore House
COMPOSITION: Gateway, c.1825, comprising pair of cut-granite panelled piers with moulded necking supporting cut-granite capping, cut-granite panelled outer piers with moulded necking supporting cut-granite capping, and iron work now missing.  Road fronted at entrance to grounds of Barraghcore House.
APPRAISAL: A gracefully-composed Classically-detailed gateway displaying particularly fine stone masonry in notoriously resilient locally-sourced County Carlow granite.  Although the loss of the original iron work has undermined the integrity of the composition the gateway continues to make a pleasing visual statement with the attendant lodge (12402113/KK-21-13) at the entrance to the grounds of Barraghcore House.

NAME: Duninga House (Doninga House)
COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, c.1775, including:

(i) Attached twenty-one-bay two-storey outbuilding on a U-shaped plan comprising eight-bay two-storey range to south, seven-bay two-storey range to west with elliptical-headed carriageway to centre ground floor, and six-bay two-storey range to north.  Undergoing extensive renovation, 2004-5, possibly to accommodate residential use.  Pitched roof on an U-shaped plan (gabled to some window openings to first floor) undergoing replacement, 2004-5, with no rainwater goods on timber eaves.  Unpainted roughcast walls over random rubble limestone construction.  Square-headed window openings with cut-granite sills, cut-granite surrounds (some having no surrounds), and two-over-two timber sash windows having some timber panelled fittings to first floor.  Square-headed door openings with cut-granite surrounds, and fittings not discerned.  Elliptical-headed carriageway to range to west with concealed red brick dressings, and no fittings.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Duninga House (Doninga House) about a courtyard.

(ii) Detached three-bay two-storey outbuilding with three-bay single-storey lateral wing to left having series of three camber-headed carriageways.  Now disused.  Pitched slate roofs with clay ridge tiles, rendered coping, and cast-iron rainwater goods.  Random squared rubble limestone walls with dressed limestone quoins to corners.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, red brick block-and-start surrounds, and louvered timber panel fittings.  Square-headed door openings with timber lintels, and timber boarded half-doors.  Series of three camber-headed carriageways with red brick voussoirs, and fittings not discerned.

(iii) Detached three-bay single-storey outbuilding with half-attic with six-bay single-storey lateral wing to right.  Now disused.  Pitched slate roofs with clay ridge tiles, rooflights, and remains of cast-iron rainwater goods on dressed rubble limestone eaves.  Random rubble limestone walls.  Square-headed door openings (one round-headed door opening to wing) with red brick dressings, timber lintels, and timber boarded doors.
APPRAISAL: Presently (2004-5) undergoing an extensive renovation programme a middle-size agricultural building arranged about a courtyard enclosed by the main house (12402105/KK-21-05) retains the original composition attributes, thereby maintaining much of the character of the site.  Additional ranges in the grounds further enhance the group and setting values of the Duninga House (Doninga House) estate in the landscape.

NAME: Duninga House (Doninga House)
COMPOSITION: Detached three-bay single-storey gate lodge, c.1800, on a T-shaped plan with single-bay single-storey return to north.  Now in private residential use.  Hipped slate roof on a T-shaped plan with clay ridge tiles, cut-granite chimney stack, and no rainwater goods on cut-granite eaves having consoles.  Random rubble limestone walls (possibly originally rendered with render removed) with dressed limestone quoins to corners.  Square-headed window openings (elliptical-headed window opening in tripartite arrangement to side (west) elevation) with cut-limestone sills, red brick dressings to elliptical-headed opening, and six-over-six timber sash windows having timber casement windows to elliptical-headed opening.  Square-headed door opening with cut-granite surround, and tongue-and-groove timber panelled door.  Set back from line of road in grounds shared with Duninga House (Doninga House).
APPRAISAL: A pleasantly-composed modest-scale gate lodge forming part of a self-contained sub-group alongside an attendant gateway (12402117/KK-21-17) with the resulting assemblage having a positive impact on the visual appeal of the landscape at the entrance to the grounds of Duninga House (Doninga House).

NAME: Duninga House (Doninga House)
COMPOSITION: Gateway, c.1800, comprising pair of cut-granite panelled piers with cut-granite capping, iron double gates, granite ashlar flanking walls supporting iron railings, and tooled cut-granite outer piers having cut-granite capping.  Road fronted at entrance to grounds of Duninga House (Doninga House).
APPRAISAL: Displaying high quality stone masonry an appealing gateway forms part of a self-contained sub-group alongside an attendant lodge (12402116/KK-21-16) with the resulting assemblage having a positive impact on the visual appeal of the landscape at the entrance to the grounds of Duninga House (Doninga House).

NAME: Duninga House (Doninga House)
COMPOSITION: Gateway, c.1800, comprising pair of cut-granite panelled piers with carved cornices supporting cut-granite capping, iron double gates, granite ashlar curved flanking walls having cut-granite coping, and cut-granite panelled outer piers having carved cornices supporting cut-granite capping.  Road fronted at entrance to grounds of Duninga House (Doninga House).
APPRAISAL: An elegantly-appointed gateway displaying particularly fine stone masonry while enriched iron work further enhances the aesthetic aspirations of the composition.  Forming a neat sub-group with an attendant gate lodge (12402118/KK-21-18) the resulting ensemble represents an appealing focal point at the entrance to the grounds of Duninga House (Doninga House).

NAME: Killure House (Garryduff Rectory)
COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, post-1902, including:

(i) Detached four-bay two-storey outbuilding with single-bay single-storey gabled advanced porch.  Extensively renovated to accommodate residential use.  Pitched slate roof (gabled to porch) with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stack, rooflight, and replacement uPVC rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Random rubble limestone walls originally rendered with render removed having dressed limestone quoins to corners.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, lintels, and replacement uPVC casement windows.  Square-headed door opening with lintel, and replacement timber panelled door.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Killure House (Garryduff Rectory).

(ii) Detached four-bay single-storey outbuilding with half-attic with four-bay single-storey mono-pitched projecting bay to left.  Extensively renovated.  Pitched slate roof (mono-pitched to projecting bay) with clay ridge tiles, rendered coping, rooflights, and iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Random rubble limestone walls originally rendered with render removed having dressed limestone quoins to corners.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, and replacement uPVC casement windows.  Square-headed door openings with replacement glazed tongue-and-groove timber panelled doors.
APPRAISAL: A collection of modest- and middle-size outbuilding ranges forming a neat self-contained group alongside the adjacent glebe house (12402110/KK-21-10) with the resulting ensemble representing an appealing feature in the local landscape.  Despite extensive renovation works that have included the removal of substantial quantities of the historic fabric the survival of the original composition attributes maintains some of the integrity of each range.

NAME: Mountrothe House (Mountrath House)
COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, c.1775, including:

(i) Detached eleven-bay two-storey outbuilding with segmental-headed carriageway to centre ground floor.  Part reroofed, c.1975.  Now disused.  Pitched slate roof with sections of replacement corrugated-iron, c.1975, clay ridge tiles, and remains of cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Unpainted fine roughcast walls over random rubble stone construction.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, concealed red brick dressings, and remains of timber fittings.  Square-headed door openings with cut-granite surrounds, and remains of timber doors.  Segmental-headed carriageway to centre ground floor with concealed red brick voussoirs having cut-granite keystones, and no fittings.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Mountrothe House (Mountrath House).

(ii) Detached two-bay single-storey outbuilding.  Reroofed, c.1950.  Hipped gabled roof with replacement corrugated-iron, c.1950, iron ridges, and no rainwater goods surviving on rendered stepped eaves.  Remains of unpainted roughcast walls over random rubble limestone construction.  Square-headed door opening with cut-granite surround, and timber boarded half-door.

(iii) Detached single-bay single-storey gable-fronted outbuilding, c.1925, with square-headed carriageway to ground floor.  Pitched (gable-fronted) corrugated-iron roof with iron ridge, and no rainwater goods on timber eaves board.  Coursed cut-stone walls in shallow courses.  Square-headed window openings with cut-stone flush sills, lintels, and timber fittings.  Square-headed carriageway to ground floor with timber lintel, and painted corrugated-iron fitting.
APPRAISAL: A collection of modest- and middle-size agricultural outbuildings forming a self-contained farmyard complex contributing significantly to the group and setting values of the Mountrothe House (Mountrath House) estate in the rural landscape.  Although individually in various states of repair each range retains most of the original form and massing, thereby maintaining the character of the ensemble.

COMPOSITION: Detached four-bay single-storey thatched cottage, c.1775.  Extended, c.1925, comprising single-bay single-storey lean-to end bay to right.  Extended, post-1994, comprising single-bay single-storey end bay to left possibly incorporating fabric of earlier outbuilding end bay, pre-1902, on site.  Hipped roof with water reed thatch having replacement rope work, post-1994, to ridge, and red brick Running bond squat chimney stack having iron flue.  Lean-to slate roof to end bay with rendered coping, and cast-iron rainwater goods.  Painted roughcast walls over random rubble stone construction having sections of mud wall construction.  Square-headed window openings with cut-stone sills, and one-over-one timber sash windows.  Square-headed door opening (previously under single-bay single-storey flat-roofed projecting porch, pre-1994, with porch removed, post-1994) with replacement tongue-and-groove timber panelled door, post-1994.  Set in own grounds perpendicular to road with painted roughcast boundary wall having rendered coping, rendered piers having concrete capping, and iron double gates.
APPRAISAL: A modest-scale house representing an important element of the mid to late eighteenth-century vernacular legacy of County Kilkenny as indicated by characteristics such as the informal arrangement of the openings, the construction in locally-sourced materials including mud, the thatched roof, and so on.  Despite a number of alteration works over the course of the twentieth century the house has historically been very well maintained to present an early aspect, thereby making a positive contribution to the character of a rural setting.

NAME: Saint Molua's Church
COMPOSITION:
Detached five-bay double-height single-cell Catholic church, dated 1859, possibly incorporating fabric of earlier Catholic chapel, pre-1840, on site with single-bay single-storey lean-to sacristy to south.
