Hipped slate roof (pitched to end bay) with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks, and cast-iron rainwater goods on overhanging rendered eaves having iron ties.  Painted roughcast walls over random rubble stone construction.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, and six-over-six timber sash windows.  Door opening not visible.  Interior with remains of timber panelled reveals/shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds.

(ii) Detached four-bay single-storey outbuilding, c.1800, possibly with half-attic.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods.  Remains of unpainted roughcast lime rendered walls over random rubble stone construction with iron tie bars.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, concealed dressings, and remains of timber fittings.  Square-headed door openings with concealed dressings, and painted corrugated-iron doors in timber frames.

(iii) Detached four-bay single-storey outbuilding, c.1800.  Now disused.  Pitched slate roof with terracotta ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods on rendered dressed limestone eaves.  Unpainted lime rendered walls over random rubble stone construction.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, concealed dressings, and remains of timber fittings.  Square-headed door openings with concealed dressings, and painted corrugated-iron doors in timber frames.
APPRAISAL: A well-composed Classically-proportioned middle-size house possibly incorporating the fabric of the medieval Sheepstown Castle (pre-1700) on site, thereby representing the continuation of a long-standing presence on site.  Despite having fallen into a slightly dishevelled state the original composition attributes survive intact together with much of the historic fabric both to the exterior and to the interior, thereby maintaining much of the integrity of the house.  A collection of modest-scale outbuilding ranges contributes to the group and setting values of a complex having historic connections with the Rothe family.

NAME: Carrickshock House (Gorman's Cottage)
COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, c.1825, including:

(i) Detached three-bay two-storey farmhouse with single-bay two-storey advanced entrance bay.  Extended, c.1875, comprising two-bay single-storey higher end block with half-dormer attic to left.  Extensively renovated.  Pitched slate roofs (gabled to half-dormer attic windows) with clay ridge tiles, red brick Running bond chimney stacks, rendered coping, rooflights, and iron rainwater goods.  Random rubble stone walls probably originally rendered with render removed retaining painted roughcast to end block.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, and replacement timber casement windows.  Square-headed door opening with replacement glazed tongue-and-groove timber panelled door.  Set in own grounds perpendicular to road.

(ii) Attached two-bay single-storey outbuilding with half-attic.  Extensively renovated to accommodate residential use.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, red brick Running bond chimney stack, and iron rainwater goods on dressed rubble stone eaves.  Random rubble stone walls probably originally rendered with render removed.  Square-headed window openings with replacement sills, lintels, some having red brick block-and-start surrounds, and replacement timber casement windows.

(iii) Attached three-bay single-storey cottage with half-dormer attic.  Extensively renovated.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and iron rainwater goods on dressed limestone eaves.  Random rubble limestone walls probably originally rendered with render removed.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, and replacement timber casement windows.  Square-headed door opening with red brick block-and-start surround, and replacement glazed tongue-and-groove timber panelled door.

(iv) Attached three-bay single-storey cottage with single-bay single-storey recessed end bay to left.  Extensively renovated.  Pitched slate roof (hipped to end bay) with clay ridge tiles, red brick Running bond chimney stacks (one squat), and iron rainwater goods on dressed rubble stone eaves.  Random rubble stone walls probably originally rendered with render removed.  Square-headed window openings with replacement sills, lintels, red brick block-and-start surrounds, and replacement timber casement windows.  Square-headed door opening with red brick block-and-start surround, and replacement glazed tongue-and-groove timber panelled door.
APPRAISAL: Forming an important component of the vernacular legacy of County Kilkenny a collection of modest-scale ranges traditionally assembled in an informal pattern about a courtyard produces an appealing cluster enhancing the scenic value of the local landscape: archival editions of the Ordnance Survey indicate that the ensemble survives as one of the last of a number of farmyard complexes once representing the built heritage of Carrickshock and the environs.  Having undergone an extensive renovation programme with some ranges adapted to an alternative use the complex nevertheless continues to make a positive contribution to the character of the locality.

NAME: Saint Brendan's Catholic Church (Saint Brandon's C
COMPOSITION:
Remains of detached five-bay double-height Catholic church, dated 1800, on a cruciform plan comprising two-bay double-height nave with single-bay double-height transepts to north and to south, two-bay double-height chancel to east having single-bay single-storey lean-to flanking bays, and single-bay single-storey gabled projecting porch to west.  In use, pre-1973.  Decommissioned, post-1983.  Dismantled, pre-2001.  Consolidated, 2001.  Now in ruins.  Pitched roofs (lean-to to flanking bays; gabled to porch) now gone with rendered coping to gables having finials to apex, rendered buttressed gabled bellcote to apex to west (with pointed-arch aperture having cast-iron bell, stringcourse, and cross finial to apex), and no rainwater goods surviving on rendered eaves.  Unpainted roughcast walls over random rubble stone construction with rendered quoins to corners supporting cross finials to west, and rusticated unpainted rendered walls to porch.  Pointed-arch window openings with cut-limestone sills, rendered surrounds, and fittings removed, pre-2001.  Pointed-arch door opening to porch with rendered voussoirs, and fittings removed, pre-2001.  Square-headed door opening into church with fittings removed, pre-2001.  Interior dismantled, pre-2001.  Set back from road in own grounds with landscaped grounds to site, decorative wrought iron gate to west in decorative wrought iron surround having cross finial over, wrought iron flanking railings having finials, and unpainted rendered terminating piers having overgrown capping.

(ii) Graveyard to site with various cut-stone markers, post-1800-post-1983
APPRAISAL: A well-composed middle-size rural parish church of modest architectural aspirations with a sparse external decorative treatment indicating an early period of construction predating Catholic Emancipation (1829).  However, although the original form and massing survive in place much of the historic fabric has been lost following dismantling works in the late twentieth century: crucially, the enriched interior scheme singled out for special attention by Maurice Craig and William Garner (Garnerman) has also been lost.  Nevertheless, the church remains an important element of the architectural heritage of Hugginstown on account of the impact on the aesthetic appeal of the village: an attendant graveyard containing a collection of markers displaying high quality craftsmanship contributes to the setting value of the composition while a screen incorporating decorative iron work of artistic design importance makes a strong visual statement in the streetscape.

NAME: Castle Morres (House)
COMPOSITION: Detached single-bay single-storey Classical-style gate lodge with dormer attic, c.1850, with prostyle tetrastyle pedimented Doric portico, and three-bay single-storey side elevations.  Renovated, c.1900, with roof remodelled to accommodate dormer attic.  Mostly refenestrated.  Now in private residential use.  Pitched (gable-fronted) slate roof remodelled, c.1900, with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stack, decorative timber bargeboards to gable having finial to apex, and cast-iron rainwater goods on slightly overhanging eaves.  Unpainted rendered, ruled and lined walls with limestone ashlar Doric pilasters to corners supporting frieze, cornice, and tongue-and-groove timber panelling to gable.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, moulded surrounds, and six-over-six timber sash windows having some replacement uPVC casement windows (pointed-arch window opening to gable with fixed-pane timber window).  Square-headed door opening under prostyle tetrastyle Doric portico on five cut-limestone steps with cut-limestone piers supporting frieze, carved cut-limestone surround to pediment, moulded surround to door opening, and glazed timber panelled door on cut-limestone step.  Set back from line of road in grounds shared with Castle Morres (House).
APPRAISAL: A picturesque small-scale gate lodge of individual character on account of the finely-crafted Classically-derived detailing surmounted by a altered roofline embellished with vaguely Gothic- or Tudor-influenced accents.  An elegant portico exhibiting high quality stone masonry enhances the formal architectural design value of the composition while the retention of much of the historic fabric maintains most of the character of the site particularly following the dispersion of the estate after the loss of the main house (c.1750; dismantled, 1940; demolished, post-1973).  Forming a neat self-contained group with an attendant gateway (12403124/KK-31-24) the resulting ensemble makes a dramatic visual statement at a prominent junction on the road leading to Kilmaganny to the west and to Newmarket to the east.

COMPOSITION: Freestanding cast-iron waterpump, c.1875, comprising banded cylindrical shaft with moulded necking supporting fluted cylindrical head having spout, curvilinear 'cow tail' handle, and fluted ogee domed capping on moulded course having finial.  Now disused.  Set back from line of road on a corner site at crossroads.
APPRAISAL: Forming an attractive, if subtle feature in the streetscape a waterpump represents an important artefact in early mass-produced cast-iron.  Although of primary significance as a reminder of the mechanisms installed for the provision of water from a local source the various raised elements identify the equal emphasis placed on aesthetic aspirations.

NAME: Rogerstown Bridge
COMPOSITION: Single-arch road bridge over river, c.1825.  Repaired, c.1950.  Random rubble limestone walls with replacement concrete block parapets, c.1950, terminating in flush piers having shallow pyramidal capping.  Single segmental arch with rendered voussoirs, and rendered soffits.  Sited spanning tributary of River Glory with grass banks to river.
APPRAISAL: An elegantly-composed modest-scale bridge representing an element of the early nineteenth-century transport heritage of County Kilkenny while making an attractive, if subtle visual impression in a rural setting.

NAME: Rossenarra House
COMPOSITION:
Gate screen, c.1825, comprising:

(i) Gateway with segmental-headed carriageway having pair of limestone ashlar piers with cut-limestone quoins, carved stringcourse to spring of arch, cut-limestone quoined voussoirs, wrought iron double gates having spear-head finials, limestone ashlar parapet having cut-limestone quoins, scroll book-end consoles, carved (moulded) cornice having blocking course over with cut-limestone coping, painted rendered flanking screen walls incorporating square-headed pedestrian gateways with carved cut-limestone surrounds having inscribed overpanels, wrought iron gates having spear-head finials, and cut-limestone coping to parapet.  Road fronted at entrance to grounds of Rossenarra House.

(ii) Pair of single-bay single-storey gate lodges to north and to south with two-bay single-storey side elevations.  Part refenestrated, c.1975.  Now disused.  Hipped slate roofs with clay ridge tiles, red brick Running bond chimney stacks, and cast-iron rainwater goods on overhanging eaves having rib consoles.  Painted rendered walls with cut-limestone quoins to corners.  Square-headed window openings originally in bipartite arrangement (in segmental-headed recess to road (east) elevation) with cut-limestone sills, and replacement timber casement windows, c.1975.  Square-headed door openings with timber panelled doors.
APPRAISAL: An elegantly-appointed gate screen built as one of a pair (with 12320002/KK-31-20-02) known as "The Grand Gates" allowing access on to the Rossenarra House estate.  Formally composed on a symmetrical plan centred on a finely-detailed gateway the design aesthetic of the composition is enhanced by carved limestone dressings displaying expert stone masonry: although of comparatively simple quality the flanking gate lodges incorporate distinctive attributes signifying a thoroughly-composed scheme.  Although subsequently decommissioned following partition from the estate holding the gateway has historically been reasonably well maintained: however, the continued replacement of the original fabric threatens to undermine the character of the composition.  In a manner similar to the second in the pair, occupying a prominent position on the road leading to Kilmaganny from Newmarket in the east the gateway forms a distinct landmark in the local landscape.

COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, c.1825, including:

(i) Detached four-bay two-storey farmhouse with single-bay single-storey gabled projecting porch to ground floor.  Now disused.  Pitched slate roof (gabled to porch) with clay ridge tiles, rendered coping, and remains of iron rainwater goods on rendered dressed limestone eaves.  Unpainted rendered walls over random rubble limestone construction.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, and louvered panel fittings.  Square-headed door opening with timber door.  Set back from road in own grounds.

(ii) Detached three-bay two-storey outbuilding.  Now disused.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods surviving on rendered dressed limestone eaves.  Unpainted roughcast walls over random rubble limestone construction with rendered buttress piers to centre ground floor.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, and louvered panel fittings.  Square-headed door opening with timber door.

(iii) Detached three-bay double-height outbuilding.  Reroofed, c.1950.  Now disused.  Pitched roof with replacement corrugated-asbestos, c.1950, iron ridge, rendered coping, and iron rainwater goods on timber eaves board.  Unpainted roughcast walls.  Square-headed window openings with rendered sills, and louvered panel fittings.
APPRAISAL: An attractive collection of modest- and middle-size agricultural buildings informally arranged about a shared farmyard courtyard producing a pleasant cluster enhancing the aesthetic value of the local landscape.  Although now disused each range retains the original essential attributes together with substantial quantities of the historic fabric, thereby maintaining much of the character of the site.

NAME: Vicarsfield Rectory (Knocktopher Glebe House)
COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, c.1800, including:

(i) Detached five-bay two-storey outbuilding.  Hipped slate roof with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stack, and no rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Painted roughcast walls over random rubble limestone construction.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, concealed dressings, and fixed-pane timber windows having lattice glazing with louvered panel fittings to first floor (most to first floor now boarded-up).  Square-headed door opening with concealed dressings, and timber boarded half-door.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Vicarsfield Rectory (Knocktopher Glebe House) about a gravel courtyard.

(ii) Detached two-bay two-storey coach house with pair of elliptical-headed carriageways to ground floor.  Hipped slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and remains of iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Unpainted roughcast walls over random rubble limestone construction.  Pair of elliptical-headed carriageways to ground floor with concealed dressings, and timber boarded double doors.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, concealed dressings, and louvered panel fittings.

(iii) Detached three-bay two-storey outbuilding.  Now disused.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Painted roughcast walls over random rubble limestone construction.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, concealed dressings, and louvered panel fittings.  Square-headed door openings with timber lintels, and remains of timber doors.
APPRAISAL: A collection of modest-scale outbuilding ranges forming a self-contained farmyard complex contributing positively to the group and setting values of the Vicarsfield Rectory (Knocktopher Glebe House) estate.  Retaining the original composition attributes together with much of the historic fabric each range presents an early aspect, thereby making a positive impression on the character of the site.

NAME: Castle Morres (House)
COMPOSITION: Gateway, c.1850, on site of earlier gateway, pre-1840, comprising pair of limestone ashlar piers with tapered panelled obelisk pilasters rising through stringcourse into carved frieze, carved cut-limestone cornice capping supporting tapered stepped panelled finials, open work cast-iron inner piers supporting cast-iron gates having foliate finials, open work cast-iron piers supporting cast-iron flanking pedestrian gateways having foliate finials, limestone ashlar outer piers with carved friezes supporting carved cut-limestone cornice capping, and remains of unpainted lime rendered curved flanking walls over random rubble stone construction with carved cut-limestone coping.  Road fronted at entrance to grounds of Castle Morres (House).
APPRAISAL: An elegantly-composed formal gateway exhibiting a robust Classical theme with Egyptian or Greek Revival motifs reminiscent of the contemporary (c.1850) gates originally allowing access to Castleboro House, Castleboro Demesne in neighbouring County Wexford and now allowing access to Farmley House (Farmleigh Manor), Farmley or Skeahanagh in the same county.  Displaying expert stone masonry throughout the carved detailing significantly enriches the architectural design value of the composition while ornamental cast-iron work further enhances the aesthetic appeal of the site.  Forming a neat self-contained group with an attendant gate lodge (12403116/KK-31-16) the resulting ensemble makes a dramatic visual statement at a prominent junction on the road leading to Kilmaganny to the west and to Newmarket to the east.

NAME: Rockview (House)
COMPOSITION: Detached four-bay two-storey house, c.1875, possibly incorporating fabric of earlier range, pre-1840, on site with two-storey canted bay window to right, and three-bay two-storey recessed lower wing to left on an L-shaped plan incorporating canted bay window to centre ground floor with single-bay two-storey projecting end bay to left.  Renovated.  Hipped slate roof (continuing into half-polygonal section to canted bay window; pitched slate roof on an L-shaped plan to wing) with clay ridge tiles (decorative clay ridge tiles to wing), rendered chimney stacks, rooflights to wing, timber bargeboards to gables having finials to apexes, and cast-iron rainwater goods on slightly overhanging rendered box eaves.  Painted rendered walls.  Square-headed window openings (including to canted bay windows; in tripartite arrangement to ground floor to end bay to wing having Venetian window opening over to first floor) with rendered sills (forming sill course to canted bay windows), and one-over-one timber sash windows (some possibly replacement with one-over-one sidelights to tripartite and to Venetian openings; three-over-six timber sash window to canted bay window to wing having one-over-two sidelights).  Segmental-headed door opening under cut-stone Doric doorcase (with columns having responsive pilasters supporting frieze, entablature, and moulded cornice supporting blocking course) with timber panelled door having fanlight.  Square-headed flanking door openings with glazed timber panelled double doors.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds on a slightly elevated site overlooking River Nore.
APPRAISAL: Occupying the position on an earlier range indicated on archival editions of the Ordnance Survey a well-composed middle-size house exhibits characteristics typical of the mid to late nineteenth-century period of construction including Classically-derived proportions, a variety of window profiles, and so on all of which identify the architectural design significance of the site.  Having been carefully maintained the house presents an early aspect with substantial quantities of the historic fabric surviving in place both to the exterior and to the interior: replica fittings to some openings further maintain the character of the site.  Positioned on a slightly elevated site overlooking the River Nore the house forms an elegant landmark in the outskirts of Inistioge: the house remains of additional importance in the locality for the associations with the Greene family.

NAME: Woodstock House
COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, c.1750, including:

(i) Detached four-bay two-storey outbuilding with series of four round-headed carriageways to ground floor.  Now disused.  Hipped slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods surviving on dressed limestone eaves.  Random rubble stone walls with cut-stone quoins to corners.  Square-headed window openings with cut-stone sills, cut-stone surrounds, and remains of timber fittings.  Series of four round-headed carriageways to ground floor with cut-stone voussoirs, and corrugated-iron panels.  Square-headed (loading) door opening to first floor side (north-east) elevation with cut-stone surround, and timber boarded door.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Woodstock House with random rubble stone boundary wall to site having cut-stone piers, and iron double gates.

(ii) Detached five-bay single-storey outbuilding with round-headed carriageway to right.  Now disused.  Hipped slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods surviving on dressed limestone eaves.  Random rubble stone walls with cut-stone quoins to corners.  Square-headed window openings with cut-stone sills, tooled cut-stone block-and-start surrounds having keystones, and no fittings surviving.  Round-headed carriageway to right with cut-stone voussoirs, and iron gate.
APPRAISAL: An appealing collection of modest-scale agricultural outbuildings exhibiting a traditional construction in unrefined locally-sourced stone with Classically-derived dressings exhibiting high quality stone masonry.  Although now disused each range retains most of the essential attributes together with substantial quantities of the historic fabric, thereby maintaining the positive contribution made to the group and setting values of the Woodstock House estate while attesting to the various services necessary to assist in the operation of a mid eighteenth-century large-scale landholding.

NAME: Woodstock House
COMPOSITION: Detached seven-bay three-storey over part-raised basement Classical-style country house, built 1745-7, with five-bay three-storey over part-raised basement Garden (south-west) Front.  Extended, 1804-6, comprising five-bay single-storey recessed lateral wings with single-bay single-storey pedimented higher breakfronts.  Burnt, 1922.  Now in ruins.  Hipped roof on a quadrangular plan behind parapet (hipped and pitched slate roofs to wings incorporating gables to pediments) now gone with chimney stacks now collapsed, and no remains of rainwater goods.  Unpainted rendered, ruled and lined walls over random rubble stone construction (collapsed in sections with entrance bay collapsed, 2001) with cut-limestone dressings including chamfered stringcourse to basement, quoins to corners, band to eaves supporting carved cornice with parapet over, and rectangular recessed panels to parapets to breakfronts to wings with remains of carved cut-limestone surround to shallow pediments over.  Square-headed window openings (oculus window openings to basement to Entrance (north-east) Front; Venetian window openings to breakfronts to wings) with cut-limestone sills, cut-limestone Gibbsian surrounds over red brick dressings incorporating double keystones (plain surrounds to Garden (south-west) Front), and no fittings surviving.  Outline of door opening approached by flight of eight cut-limestone steps.  Interior now in ruins with red brick irregular bond internal walls incorporating round-headed recessed niches to entrance hall.  Set back from road in own grounds.
APPRAISAL: The substantial remains of an elegantly-composed large-scale country house built for Sir William Fownes (n. d.) to designs prepared by Francis Bindon (c.1698-1765) with later additions completed to designs prepared by William Robertson (1770-1850) representing an important element of the architectural heritage of Inistioge and the environs.  Despite having existed as little more than a shell following destruction by fire in the early twentieth century the original composition attributes survive largely intact together with some of the fine detailing including refined limestone dressings embellishing the formal Classical architectural theme of the house.  Positioned on an elevated site in a mature woodland setting overlooking the River Nore the house remains a picturesque landmark of Romantic quality in the local landscape.  The house remains of additional importance for the historic associations with the Fownes and the Tighe families.

NAME: Ballyduff Bridge
COMPOSITION: Four-arch rubble stone road bridge over river, c.1775.  Random rubble limestone walls with cut-limestone triangular cut-waters to piers having rendered coping, and dressed limestone coping to parapets.  Pair of elliptical arches with camber elliptical flanking arches having dressed stone voussoirs, and rubble stone soffits with remains of unpainted render over.  Sited spanning Arrigle River with grass banks to river.
APPRAISAL: Exhibiting a traditional construction in unrefined locally-sourced stone a modest-scale bridge of rustic quality representing an important element of the mid to late eighteenth-century transport heritage of County Kilkenny forms an appealing landmark in a rural setting.

NAME: Ballyduff Flour Mill
COMPOSITION:
Detached four-bay three-storey flour mill and starch manufactory with attic, dated 1791, on an T-shaped plan with single-bay three-storey gabled projecting end bay to right.  In use as flour mill, 1903.  Restored, 1973.  Now in use as workshop.  Pitched slate roof on a T-shaped plan with clay ridge tiles, and cast-iron rainwater goods on dressed rubble stone eaves.  Ivy-clad remains of unpainted roughcast lime rendered walls over random rubble stone construction with remains of waterwheel over mill race.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, lintels, and remains of timber fittings with some having wrought iron bars.  Square-headed door opening with rendered surround, and timber boarded double doors.  Interior with cut-stone date stone/plaque, remains of cast-iron machinery to ground floor, and timber floors on timber beams supported on chamfered timber posts.  Set back from road in own grounds on bank overlooking mill race stemming from Arrigle River.

(ii) Detached six-bay two-storey mill manager's house, pre-1840.  Renovated.  Now in private residential use.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, red brick Running bond chimney stacks, sproketed eaves, and iron rainwater goods on rendered rubble stone eaves.  Painted roughcast walls over random rubble stone construction.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, concealed dressings, and timber casement windows.  Square-headed door opening with concealed dressings, and replacement glazed timber panelled door.
APPRAISAL: A modest-scale mill building established by Henry Waters (n. d.) of nearby Ballyduff House (12403206/KK-32-06) forming an important element of the industrial legacy of County Kilkenny having supported much of the local agricultural economy since the late eighteenth century.  Despite having been long decommissioned the original composition attributes survive in place as characterised by the disproportionate bias of solid to void featuring a regular pattern of small-scale openings while the survival of early mechanisms including the frame of a waterwheel identifies the technical or engineering importance of the site.  Forming a neat self-contained group with an attendant mill manager's house the resulting complex forms an appealing cluster in a mature rural setting.

NAME: Ballyduff House
COMPOSITION: Detached five-bay two-storey country house, built 1760, with two-bay two-storey side elevations, six-bay two-storey Garden (north-east) Front, and two-bay two-storey lower wing to right terminating in three-bay three-storey end block incorporating fabric of medieval castle, pre-1700, on site having single-bay three-storey return to north-east.  Repaired, pre-1973.  Now in use as guesthouse.  Hipped slate roof on a quadrangular plan (pitched to wing; pitched to end block on an L-shaped plan) with clay ridge tiles, roughcast chimney stacks, rooflights, and iron rainwater goods on overhanging timber eaves (on rendered eaves to wing and to end block).  Part ivy-clad unpainted roughcast walls over random rubble stone construction with rendered strips to corners, rendered stringcourse to first floor, and rendered band to eaves.  Square-headed window openings (in tripartite arrangement to ground floor side elevations; in bipartite arrangement to first floor to wing) with cut-limestone sills, six-over-nine (ground floor having two-over-three sidelights to tripartite openings) and six-over-six (first floor) timber sash windows (two-over-two timber sash windows to wing having wrought iron bars to ground floor; timber casement windows to end block).  Segmental-headed door opening with cut-limestone step, pilaster surround, and glazed cast-iron panelled double doors having fanlight.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds on an elevated site overlooking River Nore with gravel forecourt, and landscaped grounds to site.
APPRAISAL: A well-composed substantial country house incorporating the fabric of a medieval castle in the grounds, thereby continuing the long-standing occupation of a site forming an important element of the archaeological heritage of County Kilkenny.  Exhibiting qualities reminiscent of the Regency period of the following century the architectural design value of the house is identified by the harmonious arrangement of elegantly-proportioned openings centred on a Classically-detailed door, the overhang of a low-slung roof, and so on.  Having been carefully maintained the house presents an early aspect with substantial quantities of the historic fabric surviving in place both to the exterior and to the interior where timber joinery details display high quality traditional craftsmanship.  Forming an appealing landmark rising above the River Nore the house remains of additional importance in the locality for the connections with the Coghill, the Waters, the Connellan, the Solly-Flood, and the Thomas families.

NAME: Brownsbarn Bridge (Kilmacshane Bridge)
COMPOSITION: Eight-arch rubble limestone road bridge over river and flood plain, c.1825.  Random squared rubble limestone walls with cut-limestone triangular cut-waters to piers to north-west, squared rubble limestone tapered buttress pier to centre, dressed limestone buttress piers to south-east, and dressed limestone coping to parapets.  Series of three elliptical arches with single round flanking arches, series of three round arches to south-east having limestone ashlar voussoirs incorporating keystones, and squared rubble limestone soffits having remains of unpainted render over.  Sited spanning River Nore with grass banks to river including flood plain to south-east.
APPRAISAL: Making a dramatic visual statement in the River Nore valley a substantial road bridge represents an important element of the early nineteenth-century civil engineering legacy of County Kilkenny.  Representing two distinct sections producing a cohesive whole as identified by the careful grouping of the arches over the river and the associated flood plain the bridge exhibits a traditional construction in barely-refined locally-sourced stone with dressed details exhibiting high quality stone masonry.

NAME: Brownsbarn House
COMPOSITION:
Detached two-bay two-storey over basement double gable-fronted High Victorian Gothic-style country house, built 1856-63, with single-bay single-storey gabled projecting open porch to left ground floor, three-bay two-storey side elevations having canted bay window to left ground floor to south-west, and single-bay single-storey end bay with dormer attic to left extending into four-bay single-storey over basement wing to left incorporating fabric of earlier house, pre-1749, on site.  Part refenestrated.  Pitched double gable-fronted (M-profiled) slate roofs (gabled to porch; pitched to lower bay with gable to window opening in form of half-dormer attic; hipped to wing) with clay ridge tiles (decorative clay ridge tiles to wing), coursed cut-granite chamfered chimney stacks on rectangular-profiled bases having bands of coursed cut-limestone, cut-limestone coping to gables, and cast-iron rainwater goods on cut-limestone eaves having cut-granite corbels.  Coursed tooled cut-granite walls with cut-sandstone chamfered stringcourse to plinth, bands of coursed tooled cut-sandstone, and random rubble stone walls to wing.  Square-headed window openings behind combination of pointed-arch or trefoil-headed apertures with some paired, some grouped in tripartite arrangement having cut-sandstone chamfered sills (one with cut-Caen stone quatrefoil-pierced balconette on cut-limestone profiled consoles), chamfered reveals (some with cut-limestone surrounds having chamfered reveals incorporating colonette mullions with hood mouldings over), cut-granite and cut-sandstone voussoirs, and timber casement windows (some having overlights) with some one-over-one timber sash windows throughout (some replacement uPVC casement windows throughout).  Square-headed window openings to wing with cut-limestone chamfered sills, red brick block-and-start surrounds, some having cut-limestone chamfered lintels supporting red brick voussoirs forming pointed-arch relieving arches, one-over-one (basement) and two-over-two (ground floor) timber sash windows.  Trefoil-headed openings to porch on cut-marble colonettes with chamfered reveals, and no fittings.  Square-headed door opening behind pointed-arch aperture with three cut-stone steps, chamfered reveals, cut-granite and cut-sandstone voussoirs, and glazed timber panelled double doors having overlight.  Square-headed door opening to wing with cut-limestone chamfered lintel supporting red brick voussoirs forming pointed-arch relieving arch, and timber boarded door.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds with polygonal rubble granite and sandstone piers having cut-stone capping, iron double gates, and random rubble stone boundary wall having cut-stone coping.

(ii) Detached six-bay two-storey outbuilding, pre-1840.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods surviving on cut-stone eaves.  Unpainted roughcast lime rendered walls over random rubble stone construction.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, concealed dressings including timber lintels, and louvered timber panel fittings having some two-over-two timber sash windows throughout.  Square-headed door openings with concealed timber lintels, and timber boarded doors having overlights.
APPRAISAL: A very well composed substantial country house of compact appearance built as a shooting lodge for William McDougall JP (c.1810-75) in the unmistakable style of Sir Thomas Newenham Deane (1827-99) in conjunction with Benjamin Woodward (1816-61) recalling a contemporary (1865) scheme by the partnership at Turlough Park (House), Turlough, County Mayo.  Making a dramatic visual impact the construction in bands of granite and sandstone exhibits expert stone masonry while refined embellishments including dressings in locally-sourced limestone enrich the robust Ruskinian Gothic-style architectural design theme of the composition.  However, while the original composition attributes survive in place together with evidence of early internal decorative schemes the gradual replacement of the fittings to the openings with inappropriate modern articles threatens to undermine the character of the site.  Incorporating the fabric of an earlier range dating back to at least the mid eighteenth century the present house represents the continued long-standing occupation of a site having historic connections with the Roth (Rothe), the Nixon, the Lambert, the Holden, the Blackburne, and the Teighmouth families.

NAME: Bonnybrook House
COMPOSITION:
Detached three-bay two-storey farmhouse with dormer attic, c.1775, with two-bay two-storey lower return to west.  Renovated and extended comprising single-bay single-storey end bay with dormer attic to left.  Pitched slate roofs (gabled to dormer attic window) with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks, rendered coping, and iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Ivy-clad unpainted roughcast walls with rendered stringcourse to first floor.  Square-headed window openings (in tripartite arrangement to return) with cut-limestone sills (concrete sills to end bay), and replacement timber casement windows retaining one-over-one timber sash windows to return having one-over-one sidelights (one two-over-two timber sash window).  Square-headed door opening with cut-limestone step, and glazed timber panelled door having overlight.  Set back from road in own grounds.

(ii) Attached four-bay single-storey outbuilding, c.1775, to north with elliptical-headed carriageway to left.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods on dressed rubble stone eaves.  Random rubble stone walls with square apertures to eaves.  Square-headed door openings with red brick voussoirs, and no fittings.  Elliptical-headed carriageway to left with rubble stone voussoirs, and corrugated-iron double doors.
APPRAISAL: A modest-scale mid to late eighteenth-century farmhouse of unassuming architectural design pretensions retaining most of the original composition attributes together with some of the historic fabric.  However, the external expression of the house has not benefited from the insertion of inappropriate replacement fittings to many of the openings.  The house remains of additional importance in the locality for the associations with the Walsh family.

NAME: Coolmore House
COMPOSITION: Detached five-bay two-storey double-pile Classical-style country house, c.1800, with (single-storey) prostyle tetrastyle Tuscan portico to centre ground floor, two-bay two-storey side elevations, three-bay two-storey Garden (south) Front, and originally with single-bay double-height lower flanking bay to right continuing into three-bay two-storey wing on an L-shaped plan having single-bay two-storey projecting bay to right.  Renovated, post-1903, with wing truncated producing single-bay two-storey recessed lower flanking bay leading into two-bay single-storey wing having four-bay single-storey rear (south) elevation.  Hipped double-pile (M-profile) slate roof (hipped to flanking bay; hipped to wing) with rolled lead ridges, rendered chimney stack on access with ridge (rendered chimney stacks to remainder), and cast-iron rainwater goods on overhanging timber eaves having decorative timber consoles.  Unpainted roughcast walls with cut-granite stringcourse to first floor.  Square-headed window openings (in tripartite arrangement to side (east) elevation) with painted cut-limestone sills, rendered panelled surrounds to ground floor having foliate consoles supporting entablatures, moulded rendered surrounds to first floor, six-over-nine (ground floor with two-over-three sidelights to tripartite openings) and three-over-six (first floor with one-over-two sidelights to tripartite openings) timber sash windows having three-over-six timber sash windows to remainder.  Square-headed door opening under prostyle tetrastyle Tuscan portico (approached by flight of cut-granite steps having cut-granite parapet, cut-granite columns having responsive pilasters supporting frieze, carved cornice on consoles, and blocking course to parapet having raised central panel) with carved cut-granite surround, and glazed timber panelled door having overlight.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds with gravel forecourt, and landscaped grounds to site.
APPRAISAL: A very well appointed substantial country house exhibiting characteristics redolent of the emergent Regency period including elegantly-proportioned openings centred on a commanding portico, refined Classically-derived dressings, an oversailing roof, and so on all of which identify the architectural design significance of the composition.  Having been carefully maintained the house presents an early aspect with the original essential attributes in place together with most of the historic fabric both to the exterior and to the interior.  Forming the centrepiece of a large-scale landholding the house makes a positive visual impression on a slightly raised site overlooking the River Nore.  The house remains of additional importance for the associations with the Herne, the Langrishe, the Connellan, and the Solly-Flood families.

NAME: Ballycorcoran Bridge
COMPOSITION: Single-arch rubble stone road bridge over river, c.1850, possibly incorporating fabric of earlier bridge, pre-1840.  Sited spanning Arrigle River with grass banks to river.
APPRAISAL: Occupying the position on an earlier counterpart indicated on archival editions of the Ordnance Survey a small-scale bridge exhibiting a traditional construction in locally-sourced stone represents an important element of the mid nineteenth-century transport heritage of the area while making a pleasing visual statement at a crossing over the Arrigle River.

NAME: Coolmore House
COMPOSITION: Detached two-bay single-storey Classical-style gate lodge, c.1825, with single-bay single-storey lean-to recessed entrance bay to left.  Hipped slate roof (lean-to to entrance bay) with rolled lead ridges, rendered chimney stacks, and cast-iron rainwater goods on overhanging eaves.  Painted rendered walls on cut-limestone plinth with rendered panelled piers.  Square-headed window openings with painted cut-stone sills, moulded rendered surrounds, and timber casement windows having margins.  Square-headed door opening with tongue-and-groove timber panelled door.  Set back from line of road in grounds shared with Coolmore House.
APPRAISAL: A pleasantly-composed small-scale gate lodge exhibiting characteristics redolent of the Regency period including elegant Classically-derived details, an overhanging roof, and so on all of which identify the architectural design aesthetic of the site.  Forming a neat group with an attendant gateway (12403223/KK-32-23) the resulting ensemble makes a positive visual statement at the entrance to the grounds of Coolmore House.

NAME: Woodstock House
COMPOSITION: Formal garden, between 1840-90, including terraces having granite ashlar retaining walls with cut-granite coping, and flights of cut-granite steps forming swept perron having cut-granite panelled stepped buttresses.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Woodstock House.
APPRAISAL: An elegantly-composed formal garden established by Pierce Butler (n. d.) and Charles McDonald (n. d.) under the direction of Lady Louisa Tighe (1804-74) representing an important element of the landscape architectural heritage of County Kilkenny while enhancing the setting value of the Woodstock House estate.  Although the decorative visual effect achieved by the pattern of flower beds has been lost the architectural elements survive substantially intact including a graceful perron exhibiting high quality stone masonry in notoriously durable locally-sourced granite.

NAME: Woodstock House
COMPOSITION: Walled garden, c.1750, on a square plan with random rubble stone boundary wall to perimeter of site having cut-stone coping, and cut-granite quoins supporting timber double gates.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Woodstock House.
APPRAISAL: Exhibiting a traditional construction in unrefined locally-sourced stone with dressed granite accents exhibiting good masonry a substantial walled garden enhances the setting value of the Woodstock House estate while serving as a reminder of the various ancillary services necessary to facilitate the operation of a mid eighteenth-century large-scale landholding.

NAME: Woodstock House
COMPOSITION: Freestanding single-bay single-stage dovecote, c.1750, on a circular plan.  Now disused.  Conical slate roof on red brick course rising through red brick Running bond 'belvedere' into conical slate cap on red brick course.  Random rubble stone walls.  Pointed-arch door opening with red brick block-and-start surround incorporating voussoirs, and timber door.  Square-headed opening to 'belvedere' with fixed-pane fitting.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Woodstock House.
APPRAISAL: A picturesque small-scale dovecote enhancing the group and setting values of the Woodstock House estate while serving as a reminder of the various facilities put in place to facilitate the operation of a mid eighteenth-century large-scale landholding.  Having been carefully maintained to present an early aspect the dovecote makes a positive contribution to the character of the grounds.

NAME: Woodstock House
COMPOSITION: Detached four-bay single-storey outbuilding, c.1775, with square-headed carriageway to right.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and iron rainwater goods on timber eaves board over squared rubble stone eaves.  Random rubble stone walls.  Square-headed window openings with cut-stone sills, cut-stone lintels, and timber casement windows.  Square-headed carriageway to right with double doors.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Woodstock House.
APPRAISAL: Having been carefully maintained to present an early character a pleasant modest-scale outbuilding exhibiting unassuming architectural aspirations makes a positive contribution to the group and setting values of the Woodstock House estate.

NAME: Woodstock House
COMPOSITION: Detached three-bay single-storey Tudor-Revival head gardener's house with dormer attic, c.1875, with single-bay single-storey lean-to advanced porch to centre ground floor, single-bay single-storey gabled advanced end bay to left having canted bay window to ground floor, and single-bay single-storey lean-to lower end bay to right.  Part refenestrated.  Now in private residential use.  Pitched slate roof (gabled to dormer attic windows; lean-to to porch; gabled to end bay; lean-to to lower end bay) with rolled lead ridges, cut-limestone chimney stacks having yellow terracotta octagonal flues, zinc-lined cut-limestone coping to gables, and cast-iron rainwater goods.  Limestone ashlar walls.  Square-headed window openings (including to canted bay window) with cut-limestone sills, cut-limestone surrounds having chamfered reveals, some having hood mouldings over, and timber casement windows to ground floor having two-over-two timber sash windows over (some replacement uPVC casement windows throughout).  Set back from road in grounds shared with Woodstock House.
APPRAISAL: A picturesque modest-scale house built to designs attributed to Daniel Robertson (fl. 1812-49) or a follower exuding a robust Tudor Revival-flavoured architectural theme in contrast to the refined Classical elegance of the main house (12403203/KK-32-03) nearby.  Constructed entirely in locally-sourced limestone the resulting dour, almost austere quality is enlivened by intermittent detailing exhibiting particularly fine stone masonry.  Having been reasonably well maintained the house presents an early aspect, thereby maintaining the positive contribution made to the group and setting values of the Woodstock House estate: however, the gradual replacement of the original fabric with inappropriate modern articles threatens to undermine the character of the composition in the landscape.

NAME: Ballyduff House
COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, established 1760, including:

(i) Detached three-bay two-storey outbuilding with pair of square-headed carriageways to ground floor.  Reroofed, c.1950.  Pitched roof with replacement corrugated-asbestos, c.1950, clay ridge tiles, and cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Painted roughcast walls.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, concealed dressings, and timber fittings.  Square-headed door openings with timber doors.  Pair of square-headed carriageways to ground floor with timber boarded double doors.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Ballyduff House with stone cobbled courtyard.

(ii) Detached four-bay two-storey outbuilding with square-headed carriageway to ground floor.  Reroofed, c.1950.  Pitched roof with replacement corrugated-asbestos, c.1950, clay ridge tiles, and cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Painted roughcast walls.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, concealed dressings, and timber fittings including louvered panel fittings.  Square-headed carriageway to ground floor with no fittings.

(iii) Walled garden with random rubble stone boundary wall to perimeter of site incorporating dressed rubble stone breakfront having elliptical-headed carriageway with dressed limestone voussoirs, corrugated-iron door, and segmental gabled bellcote over (with round-headed aperture between dressed limestone piers having remains of cast-iron fittings, and ivy-clad archivolt).
APPRAISAL: An appealing collection of modest-scale agricultural outbuildings and related artefacts forming a self-contained farmyard complex contributing positively to the group and setting values of the Ballyduff House estate.

NAME: Ballyduff House
COMPOSITION: Gateway, built 1760, comprising pair of rusticated granite ashlar piers with cut-stone capping, iron double gates, and unpainted roughcast curved flanking walls with cut-stone coping supporting iron railings.  Road fronted at entrance to grounds of Ballyduff House.
APPRAISAL: Exhibiting high quality stone masonry a pleasantly-composed Classically-detailed gateway makes a pleasing visual statement on a corner at the entrance to the grounds of the Ballyduff House estate: enriched iron fittings further enhance the design aesthetic of the composition.

NAME: Coolmore House
COMPOSITION:
Farmyard complex, c.1850, about a courtyard including:

(i) Detached five-bay two-storey outbuilding with three-bay single-storey over basement rear (west) elevation.  Hipped slate roof with clay ridge tiles, red brick Running bond squat chimney stack, and iron rainwater goods on squared rubble stone eaves.  Remains of unpainted lime rendered walls over random rubble stone construction.  Oculus window openings to first floor with red brick surrounds, and no fittings.  Camber-headed window openings to rear (west) elevation with cut-limestone sills, red brick block-and-start surrounds incorporating voussoirs, and no fittings surviving.  Camber-headed door opening to rear (west) elevation with red brick block-and-start surround incorporating voussoirs, and no fittings surviving.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Coolmore House about a courtyard.

(ii) Attached three-bay single-storey outbuilding with attic originally detached with series of three segmental-headed carriageways.  Reroofed, c.1950.  Pitched roof with replacement corrugated-asbestos, c.1950, concrete ridge tiles, rendered coping, and iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Remains of unpainted rendered walls over random rubble stone construction.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, and remains of timber fittings.  Series of three segmental-headed carriageways forming arcade on limestone ashlar piers with cut-limestone stringcourse, cut-limestone block-and-start voussoirs, and tongue-and-groove timber panelled double doors.

(iii) Detached two-bay single-storey outbuilding.  Now disused.  Hipped slate roof with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods on squared rubble stone eaves.  Random rubble stone walls.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, red brick dressings, timber lintels, and remains of timber fittings.
APPRAISAL: A collection of modest- and middle-size agricultural outbuilding ranges formally arranged about a shared courtyard forming a self-contained farmyard complex contributing significantly to the group and setting values of the Coolmore House estate while attesting to the various services put in place in the mid nineteenth century for the purpose of assisting in the operation of a large-scale landholding.  Distinctive attributes including Classically-derived oculus openings to one range with another range incorporating an arcade displaying high quality stone masonry all serve to elevate the design aesthetic of the complex about the merely functional.  Having been reasonably well maintained each unit presents an early aspect, thereby making a positive impression on the character of the site.

NAME: Coolmore House
COMPOSITION:
Walled garden, c.1850, possibly incorporating fabric of earlier walled garden, pre-1840, on site with random rubble stone boundary wall to perimeter of site incorporating unpainted rendered pedimented frontispiece having round-headed door opening with no fittings, and surround to pediment having rectangular finial to apex.  Set back from road in grounds shared with Coolmore House.

(ii) Attached three-bay single-storey lean-to glass house with single-bay single-storey gabled entrance bay to centre.  Lean-to glazed roof (gabled to entrance bay) in timber frame with finial to apex, and iron rainwater goods.  Red brick Running bond plinth.  Square-headed window openings with fixed-pane fittings in timber frame having casement sections.  Square-headed door opening with glazed timber panelled door.
APPRAISAL: Occupying the position of a kitchen garden in existence since the early nineteenth century a substantial walled garden enhances the setting value of the Coolmore House estate while attesting to the various services put in place to assist in the operation of a large-scale landholding: a glass house of modest appearance contributes pleasantly to the aesthetic appeal of the site.

NAME: Coolmore House
COMPOSITION: Single-arch rubble stone road bridge over stream, c.1800.  Random rubble stone walls with rendered rubble stone coping to parapets.  Single segmental arch with rubble stone voussoirs, and rubble stone soffits.  Sited spanning tributary of River Nore with grass banks to stream.
APPRAISAL: A small-scale artefact of technical engineering interest forming an appealing, if subtle feature enhancing the setting value of the Coolmore House estate.

NAME: Coolmore House
COMPOSITION: Gateway, c.1825, comprising pair of open work iron piers with iron double gates having finials, and cut-limestone chamfered coping supporting sections of iron flanking railings having finials.  Road fronted at entrance to grounds of Coolmore House.
APPRAISAL: Representing an early surviving artefact in mass-produced iron an elegantly-appointed gateway exhibits a simple design quality dependent upon profiled finials for decorative effect.  Forming a neat group with an attendant gate lodge (12403212/KK-32-12) the resulting ensemble makes a positive visual statement at the entrance to the grounds of the Coolmore House estate.

NAME: Clodiagh Bridge
COMPOSITION: Single-arch rubble stone road bridge over river, c.1825.  Random squared rubble stone walls with dressed limestone rounded coping to parapets.  Single round arch with rusticated limestone voussoirs, and rubble stone soffits having remains of render over.  Sited spanning Clodiagh River with grass banks to river.
APPRAISAL: An elegantly-composed modest-scale bridge representing an important element of the early to mid nineteenth-century civil engineering heritage of County Kilkenny.  Exhibiting a traditional construction in barely-refined locally-sourced stone with Classically-derived dressings displaying high quality stone masonry the bridge forms an appealing feature rising above the Clodiagh River.

NAME: Saint Brendan's Catholic Church
COMPOSITION: Detached three-bay double-height Catholic church, built 1800, on a T-shaped plan on a corner site comprising single-bay double-height nave with single-bay single-storey gabled projecting porch to south, single-bay double-height transepts to north and to south, and single-bay double-height shallow chancel to east having single-bay single-storey sacristy to south-east.  Pitched slate roofs on a cruciform plan (gabled to porch; pitched to sacristy) with clay ridge tiles, cut-limestone coping to gables having cross finials to apexes, rooflights, and cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Unpainted roughcast walls.  Pointed-arch window openings (paired to chancel and to sacristy) with cut-limestone sills, and timber casement windows incorporating tracery (fixed-pane fittings to chancel having leaded stained glass panels; three-over-six timber sash window to porch incorporating tracery).  Square-headed door opening with tongue-and-groove timber panelled door.  Full-height interior with timber pews, carved timber Gothic-style confessional boxes, timber balustraded galleries to first floor on chamfered timber posts, and diagonal tongue-and-groove timber panelled ceiling.  Set back from line of road in own grounds on a corner site with random rubble stone boundary wall to perimeter of site having rubble stone coping, limestone ashlar tapered piers having cut-limestone capping, and iron gate.
APPRAISAL: Occupying a prominent position on a corner site a modest-scale rural parish church exhibits qualities indicating an early period of construction predating Catholic Emancipation (1829) including a pared-down plan form, a sparse external decorative treatment, and so on.  Having been carefully maintained the church presents an early aspect with substantial quantities of the historic fabric surviving in place both to the exterior and to the interior where timber dressings or fittings display good craftsmanship while stained glass panels identify the artistic design merit of the site.

NAME: Ballinvarry Bridge
COMPOSITION: Single-arch rubble stone road bridge over stream, c.1825.  Random rubble stone walls with dressed rubble stone coping to parapets.  Single round arch with dressed rubble stone voussoirs, and rubble stone soffits.  Sited spanning tributary of River Barrow with rubble limestone retaining walls to stream.
APPRAISAL: Exhibiting a traditional construction in locally-sourced stone a picturesque bridge representing a small-scale artefact of the transport heritage of County Kilkenny makes a pleasing visual impression in a rural setting.

NAME: Brandonhill House
COMPOSITION: Detached three-bay two-storey farmhouse, c.1900, possibly incorporating fabric of earlier range, pre-1840, on site with single-bay single-storey flat-roofed projecting porch to centre ground floor.  Now disused.  Hipped slate roof with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks, and remains of iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Flat roof to porch not visible behind parapet.  Part ivy-clad unpainted fine roughcast walls over random rubble stone construction with moulded rendered cornice to parapet to porch.  Square-headed window openings with cut-stone sills, and one-over-one timber sash windows.  Set back from road in own grounds with unkempt grounds to site.
APPRAISAL: Despite having fallen into some disrepair following a period of disuse a modest-scale house retains the original form and massing together with most of the historic fabric, thereby making a positive impression on the character of the locality.

NAME: Cullintra House
COMPOSITION: Detached three-bay two-storey house, c.1750.  Now in use as guesthouse.  Hipped slate roof with clay ridge tiles, rendered chimney stacks, and iron rainwater goods on slightly overhanging eaves.  Ivy-clad unpainted rendered walls.  Square-headed window openings with cut-stone sills, and two-over-two timber sash windows.  Segmental-headed door opening with timber panelled door having sidelights, and fanlight.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Set back from road in own grounds with landscaped grounds to site.
APPRAISAL: A well-composed house of the middle-size retaining the original form and massing together with most of the historic fabric both to the exterior and to the interior, thereby maintaining the status as an important element of the mid eighteenth-century domestic architectural legacy of County Kilkenny.

NAME: Kilmacoliver Corn Mill
COMPOSITION:
Corn mill complex, c.1800, including:

(i) Detached five-bay two-storey mill owner's house with single-bay single-storey lean-to advanced open porch to centre ground floor, single-bay single-storey end bay to right, and single-bay single-storey return to south-east.  Pitched slate roofs (lean-to to porch) with clay ridge tiles, red brick Running bond chimney stack, rendered coping, and cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Unpainted roughcast walls with rendered strips to corners, and painted rendered piers to porch.  Square-headed window openings with painted cut-stone sills, and two-over-two timber sash windows having iron bars to ground floor.  Square-headed door opening with timber boarded half-door having herring bond-pattern tongue-and-groove panelled upper leaf.  Set in own grounds perpendicular to road with random rubble stone boundary wall to perimeter of site.

(ii) Detached three-bay two-storey mill with single-bay two-storey gabled projecting lower bay to left, and four-bay two-storey lower range to right.  In use, 1903.  Decommissioned, post-1955.  Now disused.  Pitched slate roofs (gabled to end bay) with clay ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods on dressed rubble stone eaves.  Random rubble stone walls.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, dressed rubble stone lintels, and timber boarded panel fittings.  Square-headed door openings (on slate-lined rubble stone loading platform to main block) with dressed rubble stone lintels, and timber boarded doors.  

(iii) Detached five-bay single-storey outbuilding.  Pitched slate roof with terracotta ridge tiles, rendered coping, and no rainwater goods on rendered rubble stone eaves.  Painted random rubble stone walls.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, timber lintels, and timber fittings.  Square-headed door openings with timber lintels, and timber boarded doors.

(iv) Detached seven-bay single-storey outbuilding with half-attic with elliptical-headed carriageway to right ground floor.  Pitched slate roof with clay ridge tiles, rendered coping, and no rainwater goods on iron mesh-lined eaves.  Random rubble stone walls.  Square-headed window openings with slate-lined sills, dressed stone lintels, and timber casement windows having some timber boarded panel fittings.  Square-headed door openings (including one to first floor to side elevation approached by flight of six slate-lined rubble stone steps) with dressed stone lintels, and timber boarded doors having some timber boarded half-doors.  Elliptical-headed carriageway to right ground floor with dressed rubble stone voussoirs, and fittings not visible.
APPRAISAL: A modest-scale corn mill complex forming an important element of the industrial legacy of County Kilkenny having supported the local agricultural economy since the late eighteenth or early nineteenth century.  Although having been decommissioned in the mid twentieth century the mill proper survives remarkably intact with the original composition attributes in place together with most of the historic fabric.  The associated house expresses an early provenance on account of characteristics including the disproportionate bias of solid to void in the massing incorporating a regular pattern of small-scale openings: now accommodating a private use the house has historically been well maintained to present an early aspect.  A collection of modest-scale ancillary ranges enhances the group and setting values of the cluster in the rural landscape.

NAME: John Delaney
COMPOSITION:
Detached four-bay two-storey house, c.1900, possibly incorporating fabric of earlier range, pre-1840, on site with shopfront to right ground floor.  Now disused to right ground floor.  Pitched slate roof with decorative terracotta ridge tiles having trefoil apertures, red brick Running bond chimney stacks having stringcourses, and cast-iron rainwater goods on timber eaves.  Unpainted rendered, ruled and lined walls with rendered quoins to ends.  Square-headed window openings with cut-limestone sills, rendered surrounds having moulded reveals, and one-over-one timber sash windows.  Square-headed door opening with rendered surround on cut-limestone base having moulded reveals, and timber panelled door having overlight.  Timber shopfront to right ground floor on a symmetrical plan with panelled pilasters, fixed-pane display windows behind decorative iron screens having overlights, timber panelled double doors having overlight, glazed timber fascia having consoles, and moulded cornice.  Interior with timber panelled reveals/shutters to window openings.  Set back from line of road with tarmacadam verge to front.

(ii) Attached three-bay single-storey outbuilding, c.1900, to east with pair of square-headed carriageways, and single-bay single-storey lower end bay to right having camber-headed carriageway.  Pitched slate roofs with terracotta ridge tiles, and no rainwater goods on timber eaves.  Unpainted roughcast walls over random rubble limestone construction.  Square-headed door opening with red brick block-and-start surround, and timber door.  Pair of square-headed carriageways with red brick block-and-start surrounds, and no fittings.  Camber-headed carriageway to end bay with cut-limestone voussoirs, and painted corrugated-iron double doors.

(iii) Attached three-bay single-storey outbuilding, c.1900, to east possibly originally detached incorporating fabric of earlier range, pre-1840, on site.  Pitched slate roof with terracotta ridge tiles, and cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered rubble stone eaves.  Painted roughcast lime rendered walls.  Square-headed window openings with no sills, concealed dressings, and timber fittings.  Square-headed door opening with timber lintel, and timber door.
APPRAISAL: A pleasant modest-scale range accommodating residential and commercial spaces in a wholly-integrated composition.  Having been carefully maintained the house presents an early aspect with the original form and massing in place together with most of the historic fabric both to the exterior and to the interior: a finely-crafted shopfront of considerable artistic design merit displaying good craftsmanship has also been fully retained despite the apparent cessation of the commercial venture.  A collection of attendant outbuilding ranges enhances the group and setting values of the site in the locality.

NAME: Saint Nicholas's Catholic Church
COMPOSITION:
Detached five-bay double-height single-cell Catholic church, dated 1885, possibly incorporating fabric of earlier Catholic chapel, pre-1840, on site.  Extensively renovated, 1985, with interior remodelled.  Pitched slate roof with decorative terracotta ridge tiles, cross finial to apex to east, and iron rainwater goods on overhanging rendered eaves having iron ties.  Unpainted rendered, ruled and lined walls with pair of inscribed cut-limestone date stones/plaques, rendered strips to corners, and tooled cut-limestone stepped buttresses to nave having cut-limestone coping.  Pointed-arch window openings (blind to gable to east) with cut-stone sills, cut-granite block-and-start surrounds to east having chamfered reveals, rendered frames supporting hood mouldings over, and fixed-pane fittings to all openings having leaded stained glass panels.  Pointed-arch door opening with cut-granite surround having chamfered reveals, rendered frames supporting hood moulding over, replacement tongue-and-groove timber panelled double doors, 1985, having side panels, and overlight.  Full-height interior remodelled, 1985.  Set back from road in own grounds with tooled limestone ashlar piers having cut-limestone capping, iron double gates having decorative finials, limestone ashlar chamfered coping supporting iron flanking railings having decorative finials, and tooled limestone ashlar outer piers having cut-limestone capping.

(ii) Graveyard to site with various cut-stone markers, pre-1840-present.

(iii) Freestanding belfry, dated 1941, comprising unpainted rendered tapered base on a square plan on cut-limestone step with moulded rendered surround framing iron plaque, moulded rendered capping supporting cast-iron pillars having foliate detailing, and cast-iron bell in iron frame.
APPRAISAL: Occupying the position of an earlier chapel indicated on archival editions of the Ordnance Survey a middle-size church built for W. Maher (n. d.) and James Brennan (n. d.) expresses modest architectural aspirations despite the apparent increasing confidence and prosperity of the local Catholic community following Emancipation (1829) earlier in the century.  Sparsely-detailed the architectural design value of the church is indicated by the balanced arrangement of pleasantly-proportioned Gothic-style openings with some incorporating enriched surrounds, the limestone dressings displaying high quality stone masonry, and so on.  Although presenting an early external aspect the original interior has been lost as a consequence of alteration works carried out following the Second Vatican Council (1963-5): delicate stained glass panels thereby make an important contribution to the artistic achievement of the church.  Enhancing the setting values of the church an attendant graveyard contains a collection of markers exhibiting high quality craftsmanship while a belfry is of significance for the connections with James Kelly (n. d.) of neighbouring County Wexford.

NAME: E. Power
COMPOSITION: Detached four-bay two-storey house, c.1825, with single-bay single-storey gable-fronted end bay with half-dormer attic to right, and single-bay single-storey return to north-west.  Renovated, c.1900, with shopfront inserted to right ground floor.  Now disused.  Pitched slate roofs (gable-fronted to end bay) with clay ridge tiles, red brick Running bond chimney stack having stringcourse, decorative timber bargeboards to gable having finials to apex, and cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves.  Painted rendered, ruled and lined walls to front (south-east) elevation with rendered channelled piers to ends, and unpainted roughcast walls to remainder.  Square-headed window openings with painted cut-limestone sills, two-over-two timber sash windows having some one-over-one timber sash windows throughout, and fixed-pane timber window to ground floor end bay incorporating cast-iron post box, c.1925.  Square-headed door opening with timber panelled door having overlight.  Rendered shopfront, c.1900, to right ground floor with pilasters (some paired), timber boarded shutters to display window, tongue-and-groove timber panelled door, fascia having raised lettering, decorative consoles, and moulded cornice.  Square-headed door opening to end bay with timber boarded door.  Interior with timber panelled shutters to window openings.  Road fronted.
APPRAISAL: A well-composed modest-scale house retaining the original form and massing together with most of the historic fabric both to the exterior and to the interior, thereby making a positive impression on the historic character of the locality.  Indicated as a post office on archival editions of the Ordnance Survey a finely-detailed shopfront exhibiting high quality craftsmanship has survived the decommissioning of the site, thereby identifying the artistic design merit of the composition.

NAME: Lismateige Bridge
COMPOSITION: Three-arch rubble stone road bridge over river, c.1800.  Random rubble stone walls with dressed conglomerate stone triangular cut-waters to piers having rendered coping, and rendered rounded coping to parapets.  Series of three segmental arches with dressed conglomerate stone voussoirs, and rubble stone soffits.  Sited spanning Pollanassa River with grass banks to river.
APPRAISAL: Exhibiting a traditional construction in locally-sourced stone with barely-refined dressings a modest-scale bridge forming an appealing feature at a crossing over the Pollanassa River forms an important element of the late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century civil engineering heritage of County Kilkenny.

NAME: Harristown Bridge
COMPOSITION: Two-arch rubble stone road bridge over river, c.1875, probably incorporating fabric of earlier bridge, pre-1840, on site.  Remains of unpainted rendered walls over random rubble stone construction with rendered triangular cut-water to central pier having rendered coping, rendered outer piers over random rubble stone construction, and rendered rounded coping to parapets.  Pair of segmental arches with red brick (header course) voussoirs, and rubble stone soffits having traces of render over.  Sited spanning Pollanassa River with grass banks to river.
APPRAISAL: Forming an elegant landmark rising above the Pollanassa River a well-composed modest-scale bridge probably incorporates the fabric of an earlier crossing indicated on archival editions of the Ordnance Survey, thereby representing the civil engineering achievements of two periods in the nineteenth century.  Red brick accents embellishing the gracefully-profiled arches introduce a subtle sense of polychromy to an otherwise austere bridge exhibiting a traditional construction in locally-sourced rubble stone.

NAME: Lukeswell Bridge
COMPOSITION: Four-arch limestone road bridge over river, c.1825.  Coursed squared limestone walls with squared limestone triangular cut-waters to piers, batter to abutment walls, and squared limestone coping to parapets.  Series of four segmental arches with tooled cut-limestone voussoirs, and rendered soffits.  Sited spanning confluence of Derrylacky River and Black Water River with grass banks to river.
APPRAISAL: A pleasantly-composed modest-scale bridge forming an attractive feature in the centre of Lukeswell at the confluence of the Derrylacky River and the Black Water River.  Exhibiting a traditional construction in locally-sourced stone with refined dressings exhibiting high quality masonry the bridge forms an important element of the early nineteenth-century transport heritage of County Kilkenny.

COMPOSITION: Single-arch limestone railway bridge over road, opened 1853.  Irregular coursed rock-faced cut-limestone walls (including to battered abutment walls) with cut-granite coping including to parapets supporting replacement steel railings.  Single elliptical arch with tooled cut-limestone surround, tooled cut-granite stringcourse to spring of arch, cut-granite voussoirs, and tooled cut-limestone soffits.  Sited spanning road with grass banks to road.
APPRAISAL: An elegantly-appointed bridge built as one of a pair (with 12403603/KK-36-03) forming part of a group of three railway bridges (with 12403604/KK-36-04) in the immediate locality representing an important element of the transport heritage of County Kilkenny on account of the associations with the development of the Waterford and Maryborough [Portlaoise] Branch extension of the Great Southern and Western Railway line by the Waterford and Kilkenny Railway Company.  Constructed in locally-sourced County Kilkenny limestone the bridge exhibits the high quality stone masonry typically associated with such projects with particular emphasis on the Classically-derived cut-granite accents enlivening the architectural design value of the composition.

COMPOSITION: Single-arch railway bridge over river, opened 1853.  Irregular coursed rock-faced cut-conglomerate stone walls (including to battered abutment walls) with cut-limestone coping including to parapets supporting replacement steel railings.  Single round arch with tooled cut-conglomerate stone surround, tooled cut-limestone stringcourse to spring of arch, tooled cut-limestone voussoirs, and tooled cut-limestone soffits.  Sited spanning Black Water River with grass banks to river.
APPRAISAL: A gracefully-appointed bridge built as one of a pair (with 12403602/KK-36-02) forming part of a group of three railway bridges (with 12403604/KK-36-04) in the immediate locality representing an important element of the transport heritage of County Kilkenny on account of the associations with the development of the Waterford and Maryborough [Portlaoise] Branch extension of the Great Southern and Western Railway line by the Waterford and Kilkenny Railway Company.  Constructed in locally-sourced stone the bridge exhibits the high quality stone masonry typically associated with such projects with particular emphasis on the Classically-derived cut-limestone accents enlivening the architectural design value of the composition.

NAME: Glenpipe Bridge
COMPOSITION: Two-arch rubble stone road bridge over river, c.1800.  Random rubble stone walls with cut-limestone triangular cut-water to pier, and squared rubble limestone coping to parapets.  Pair of segmental arches with cut-limestone voussoirs, and squared rubble stone soffits.  Sited spanning Arrigle River with grass banks to river.
APPRAISAL: Displaying a traditional construction in unrefined stone with limestone dressings displaying high quality stone masonry a modest-scale bridge representing an element of the late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century transport legacy of County Kilkenny forms a picturesque, if subtle landmark at a crossing over the Arrigle River.

NAME: Saint David's Catholic Church (Mullinarrigle)
COMPOSITION:
Detached six-bay double-height Catholic church, c.1875, on a cruciform plan on a corner site incorporating fabric of earlier Catholic chapel, pre-1840, on site comprising four-bay double-height nave with single-bay (two-bay deep) double-height transepts to north and to south, single-bay double-height shallow chancel to east extending into single-bay single-storey sacristy to east, and single-bay three-stage entrance tower to west on a square plan having pyramidal spire.  Pitched slate roofs on a cruciform plan (pitched to sacristy) with clay ridge tiles, rendered coping to gables, and cast-iron rainwater goods on rendered eaves having iron ties.  Limestone ashlar elongated pyramidal spire to tower behind parapet with ball finial to apex incorporating open cross.
